<div class="mw-body-content mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Country in Southeast Asia</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">For other uses, see <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Vietnam_(disambiguation)" title="Vietnam (disambiguation)">Vietnam (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<p>

<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1097025294">.mw-parser-output .side-box{margin:4px 0;box-sizing:border-box;border:1px solid #aaa;font-size:88%;line-height:1.25em;background-color:#f9f9f9}.mw-parser-output .side-box-abovebelow,.mw-parser-output .side-box-text{padding:0.25em 0.9em}.mw-parser-output .side-box-image{padding:2px 0 2px 0.9em;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .side-box-imageright{padding:2px 0.9em 2px 0;text-align:center}@media(min-width:500px){.mw-parser-output .side-box-flex{display:flex;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .side-box-text{flex:1}}@media(min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .side-box{width:238px}.mw-parser-output .side-box-right{clear:right;float:right;margin-left:1em}.mw-parser-output .side-box-left{margin-right:1em}}</style><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1092331828">@media(min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .contains-special-characters{width:22em}}</style><div class="side-box metadata side-box-right contains-special-characters noprint selfref">
<div class="side-box-flex">
<div class="side-box-image"><img alt="" data-file-height="779" data-file-width="512" decoding="async" height="40" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Chu_nom.svg/26px-Chu_nom.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Chu_nom.svg/39px-Chu_nom.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Chu_nom.svg/52px-Chu_nom.svg.png 2x" width="26"/></div>
<div class="side-box-text plainlist"><b>This article contains <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_language" title="Vietnamese language">Vietnamese</a> text.</b> Without proper <a href="/wiki/Help:Multilingual_support_(East_Asian)" title="Help:Multilingual support (East Asian)">rendering support</a>, you may see <a href="/wiki/Specials_(Unicode_block)#Replacement_character" title="Specials (Unicode block)">question marks, boxes, or other symbols</a> instead of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ch%E1%BB%AF_n%C3%B4m" title="Chữ nôm">chữ nôm</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ch%E1%BB%AF_H%C3%A1n" title="Chữ Hán">chữ Hán</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_alphabet" title="Vietnamese alphabet">chữ quốc ngữ</a>.</div></div>
</div>
<p><b>Vietnam</b>, or <b>Viet Nam<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-11"><a href="#cite_note-11">[n 3]</a></sup></b> (<a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_language" title="Vietnamese language">Vietnamese</a>: <i lang="vi">Việt Nam</i>, <small></small><span class="IPA" lang="vi-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Vietnamese" title="Help:IPA/Vietnamese">[vîət nāːm]</a></span> <span class="nowrap" style="font-size:85%">(<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:Vietnam.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" decoding="async" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/></a></span><a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/cb/Vietnam.ogg" title="Vietnam.ogg">listen</a></span></span>)</span>), officially the <b>Socialist Republic of Vietnam</b>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-12"><a href="#cite_note-12">[n 4]</a></sup> is a country in <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a>, at the eastern edge of <a href="/wiki/Mainland_Southeast_Asia" title="Mainland Southeast Asia">mainland Southeast Asia</a>, with an area of 311,699 square kilometres (120,348 sq mi) and population of 96 million, making it the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_population" title="List of countries and dependencies by population">fifteenth-most populous country</a>. Vietnam borders <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a> to the north, <a href="/wiki/Laos" title="Laos">Laos</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cambodia" title="Cambodia">Cambodia</a> to the west, and shares <a href="/wiki/Maritime_boundary" title="Maritime boundary">maritime borders</a> with <a href="/wiki/Thailand" title="Thailand">Thailand</a> through the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Thailand" title="Gulf of Thailand">Gulf of Thailand</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a>, <a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">Indonesia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Malaysia" title="Malaysia">Malaysia</a> through the <a href="/wiki/South_China_Sea" title="South China Sea">South China Sea</a>. Its capital is <a href="/wiki/Hanoi" title="Hanoi">Hanoi</a> and largest city <a href="/wiki/Ho_Chi_Minh_City" title="Ho Chi Minh City">Ho Chi Minh City</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-13"><a href="#cite_note-13">[n 5]</a></sup>
</p><p>Vietnam was inhabited by the <a href="/wiki/Paleolithic" title="Paleolithic">Paleolithic</a> age, with states established in the first millennium BC on the <a href="/wiki/Red_River_Delta" title="Red River Delta">Red River Delta</a> in modern-day <a href="/wiki/Northern_Vietnam" title="Northern Vietnam">northern Vietnam</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Han_dynasty" title="Han dynasty">Han dynasty</a> annexed Northern and Central Vietnam under <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_under_Chinese_rule" title="Vietnam under Chinese rule">Chinese rule</a> from 111 BC, until the <a href="/wiki/Ng%C3%B4_dynasty" title="Ngô dynasty">first dynasty</a> emerged in 939. Successive <a href="/wiki/List_of_Vietnamese_dynasties" title="List of Vietnamese dynasties">monarchical dynasties</a> absorbed Chinese influences through <a href="/wiki/Confucianism" title="Confucianism">Confucianism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">Buddhism</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Nam_ti%E1%BA%BFn" title="Nam tiến">expanded southward</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Mekong_Delta" title="Mekong Delta">Mekong Delta</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Cham%E2%80%93Vietnamese_wars" title="History of the Cham–Vietnamese wars">conquering</a> <a href="/wiki/Champa" title="Champa">Champa</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_dynasty" title="Nguyễn dynasty">Nguyễn</a>—the last imperial dynasty—fell to <a href="/wiki/French_Indochina" title="French Indochina">French colonisation</a> in 1887. Following the <a href="/wiki/August_Revolution" title="August Revolution">August Revolution</a>, the nationalist <a href="/wiki/Viet_Minh" title="Viet Minh">Viet Minh</a> under the leadership of communist revolutionary <a href="/wiki/Ho_Chi_Minh" title="Ho Chi Minh">Ho Chi Minh</a> proclaimed <a href="/wiki/Proclamation_of_Independence_of_the_Democratic_Republic_of_Vietnam" title="Proclamation of Independence of the Democratic Republic of Vietnam">independence</a> from France in 1945.
</p><p>Vietnam went through prolonged warfare in the 20th century. After <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, France returned to reclaim colonial power in the <a href="/wiki/First_Indochina_War" title="First Indochina War">First Indochina War</a>, from which Vietnam emerged victorious in 1954. The <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_War" title="Vietnam War">Vietnam War</a> began shortly after, during which the nation was divided into communist <a href="/wiki/North_Vietnam" title="North Vietnam">North</a> supported by the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a> and <a href="/wiki/China_in_the_Vietnam_War" title="China in the Vietnam War">China</a>, and anti-communist <a href="/wiki/South_Vietnam" title="South Vietnam">South</a> supported by the <a href="/wiki/United_States_in_the_Vietnam_War" title="United States in the Vietnam War">United States</a>. Upon the <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_Saigon" title="Fall of Saigon">North Vietnamese victory</a> in 1975, Vietnam reunified as a <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">unitary</a> <a href="/wiki/Socialist_state" title="Socialist state">socialist state</a> under the <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Vietnam" title="Communist Party of Vietnam">Communist Party of Vietnam</a> (CPV) in 1976. An ineffective <a href="/wiki/Planned_economy" title="Planned economy">planned economy</a>, a trade embargo by the <a href="/wiki/Western_world" title="Western world">West</a>, and wars with <a href="/wiki/Cambodian%E2%80%93Vietnamese_War" title="Cambodian–Vietnamese War">Cambodia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sino-Vietnamese_War" title="Sino-Vietnamese War">China</a> crippled the country further. In 1986, the CPV initiated <a href="/wiki/%C4%90%E1%BB%95i_M%E1%BB%9Bi" title="Đổi Mới">economic and political reforms</a> similar to the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_economic_reform" title="Chinese economic reform">Chinese economic reform</a>, transforming the country to a <a href="/wiki/Market_economy" title="Market economy">market</a>-oriented economy. The reforms facilitated Vietnamese reintegration into <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Global_economy" title="Global economy">global economy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Global_politics" title="Global politics">politics</a>. 
</p><p>A <a href="/wiki/Developing_country" title="Developing country">developing country</a> with a lower-middle-income economy, Vietnam is nonetheless one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_real_GDP_growth_rate" title="List of countries by real GDP growth rate">fastest growing economies</a> of the 21st century, with GDP predicted to rival <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Developed_nation" title="Developed nation">developed nations</a> by 2050. Vietnam has <a href="/wiki/Corruption_in_Vietnam" title="Corruption in Vietnam">high levels of corruption</a>, <a href="/wiki/Censorship_in_Vietnam" title="Censorship in Vietnam">censorship</a> and a poor <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Vietnam" title="Human rights in Vietnam">human rights record</a>; the country <a href="/wiki/International_rankings_of_Vietnam" title="International rankings of Vietnam">ranks among the lowest</a> in international measurements of <a href="/wiki/Civil_liberties" title="Civil liberties">civil liberties</a>, <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_the_press" title="Freedom of the press">freedom of the press</a> and <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_religion_in_Vietnam" title="Freedom of religion in Vietnam">freedom of religion and ethnic minorities</a>. It is part of international and intergovernmental institutions including the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Association_of_Southeast_Asian_Nations" title="Association of Southeast Asian Nations">ASEAN</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Asia-Pacific_Economic_Cooperation" title="Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation">APEC</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Comprehensive_and_Progressive_Agreement_for_Trans-Pacific_Partnership" title="Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership">CPTPP</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Non-Aligned_Movement" title="Non-Aligned Movement">Non-Aligned Movement</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_internationale_de_la_Francophonie" title="Organisation internationale de la Francophonie">OIF</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">WTO</a>. It has assumed a seat on the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">United Nations Security Council</a> twice.
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Names_of_Vietnam" title="Names of Vietnam">Names of Vietnam</a></div>
<p>The name <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi">Việt Nam</i></span> (<small>Vietnamese pronunciation: </small><span class="IPA" lang="vi-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Vietnamese" title="Help:IPA/Vietnamese">[viə̀t naːm]</a></span>, <a href="/wiki/Ch%E1%BB%AF_H%C3%A1n" title="Chữ Hán">chữ Hán</a>: <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1051880798">.mw-parser-output .vi-nom{font-family:"Han-Nom Gothic","Nom Na Tong","Han-Nom Ming","Han-Nom Minh","HAN NOM A","HAN NOM B","Han-Nom Kai","TH-Khaai-TP0","TH-Khaai-TP2","TH-Khaai-PP0","TH-Khaai-PP2","TH-Sung-PP0","TH-Sung-PP2","TH-Sung-TP0","TH-Sung-TP2","TH-Sy-P0","TH-Sy-P2","TH-Ming-JP0","TH-Ming-JP2","Sun-ExtA","Sun-ExtB","Ming-Lt-HKSCS-UNI-H","Ming-Lt-HKSCS-ExtB","HanaMinA","HanaMinB","HanaMin","MingLiU","MingLiU-ExtB","MingLiU HKSCS","MingLiU HKSCS-ExtB","SimSun","SimSun-ExtB","FZKaiT-Extended","FZKaiT-Extended(SIP)",sans-serif}.mw-parser-output .vi-nom.ext{font-family:"Han-Nom Gothic","Han-Nom Ming","Han-Nom Minh","TH-Khaai-TP2","TH-Khaai-PP2","TH-Sung-PP2","TH-Sung-TP2","TH-Sy-P0","TH-Sy-P2","TH-Ming-JP2","BabelStone Han","Sun-ExtB","MingLiU HKSCS-ExtB","Ming-Lt-HKSCS-ExtB","HanaMinB","Han-Nom Kai",sans-serif}</style><span class="vi-nom" lang="vi-Hani"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E8%B6%8A%E5%8D%97" title="wikt:越南">越南</a></span>), literally “Viet south”, means “Viet of the South” per Vietnamese word order or “South of the Viet” per <a href="/wiki/Classical_Chinese" title="Classical Chinese">Classical Chinese</a> word order.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Brindley_2015_p27_14-0"><a href="#cite_note-Brindley_2015_p27-14">[9]</a></sup> A variation of the name, <a href="/wiki/Nanyue" title="Nanyue">Nanyue</a> (or Nam Việt, <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1051880798" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><span class="vi-nom" lang="vi-Hani"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%8D%97%E8%B6%8A" title="wikt:南越">南越</a></span>), was first documented in the 2nd century BC.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWoods200238_15-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWoods200238-15">[10]</a></sup> The term "<a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Vi%E1%BB%87t" title="wikt:Việt">Việt</a>" (Yue) (<a href="/wiki/Chinese_language" title="Chinese language">Chinese</a>: <span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E8%B6%8A" title="wikt:越">越</a></span></span>; <a href="/wiki/Pinyin" title="Pinyin">pinyin</a>: <i>Yuè</i>; <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cantonese_Yale" title="Cantonese Yale">Cantonese Yale</a>: <i>Yuht</i>; <a href="/wiki/Wade%E2%80%93Giles" title="Wade–Giles">Wade–Giles</a>: <i>Yüeh<sup>4</sup></i>; <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_language" title="Vietnamese language">Vietnamese</a>: <i lang="vi"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Vi%E1%BB%87t" title="wikt:Việt">Việt</a></i>) in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Early_Middle_Chinese" title="Early Middle Chinese">Early Middle Chinese</a> was first written using the <a href="/wiki/Logogram" title="Logogram">logograph</a> "戉" for an axe (a homophone), in <a href="/wiki/Oracle_bone" title="Oracle bone">oracle bone</a> and bronze inscriptions of the late <a href="/wiki/Shang_dynasty" title="Shang dynasty">Shang dynasty</a> (<span title="circa">c.</span><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 1200</span> BC), and later as "越".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENormanMei1976_16-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENormanMei1976-16">[11]</a></sup> At that time it referred to a people or chieftain to the northwest of the Shang.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMeacham1996_17-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMeacham1996-17">[12]</a></sup> In the early 8th century BC, a tribe on the middle <a href="/wiki/Yangtze" title="Yangtze">Yangtze</a> were called the <a href="/wiki/Yangyue" title="Yangyue">Yangyue</a>, a term later used for peoples further south.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMeacham1996_17-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMeacham1996-17">[12]</a></sup> Between the 7th and 4th centuries BC Yue/Việt referred to the <a href="/wiki/Yue_(state)" title="Yue (state)">State of Yue</a> in the lower Yangtze basin and its people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENormanMei1976_16-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENormanMei1976-16">[11]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMeacham1996_17-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMeacham1996-17">[12]</a></sup> From the 3rd century BC the term was used for the non-Chinese populations of south and southwest China and northern Vietnam, with particular ethnic groups called <a href="/wiki/Minyue" title="Minyue">Minyue</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ouyue" title="Ouyue">Ouyue</a>, Luoyue (Vietnamese: <a href="/wiki/L%E1%BA%A1c_Vi%E1%BB%87t" title="Lạc Việt">Lạc Việt</a>), etc., collectively called the <a href="/wiki/Baiyue" title="Baiyue">Baiyue</a> (Bách Việt, <a href="/wiki/Chinese_language" title="Chinese language">Chinese</a>: <span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%99%BE%E8%B6%8A" title="wikt:百越">百越</a></span></span>; <a href="/wiki/Pinyin" title="Pinyin">pinyin</a>: <i>Bǎiyuè</i>; <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cantonese_Yale" title="Cantonese Yale">Cantonese Yale</a>: <i>Baak Yuet</i>; <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_language" title="Vietnamese language">Vietnamese</a>: <i lang="vi">Bách Việt</i>; "Hundred Yue/Viet"; ).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENormanMei1976_16-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENormanMei1976-16">[11]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMeacham1996_17-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMeacham1996-17">[12]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEYue_Hashimoto19721_18-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEYue_Hashimoto19721-18">[13]</a></sup> The term Baiyue/Bách Việt first appeared in the book <i><a href="/wiki/L%C3%BCshi_Chunqiu" title="Lüshi Chunqiu">Lüshi Chunqiu</a></i> compiled around 239 BC.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKnoblockRiegel2001510_19-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKnoblockRiegel2001510-19">[14]</a></sup> By the 17th and 18th centuries AD, educated Vietnamese apparently referred to themselves as <i>nguoi Viet</i> (Viet people) or <i>nguoi nam</i> (southern people).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELieberman2003405_20-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELieberman2003405-20">[15]</a></sup>
</p><p>The form <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi">Việt Nam</i></span> (<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1051880798" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><span class="vi-nom" lang="vi-Hani"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E8%B6%8A%E5%8D%97" title="wikt:越南">越南</a></span>) is first recorded in the 16th-century oracular poem <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/S%E1%BA%A5m_Tr%E1%BA%A1ng_Tr%C3%ACnh" title="Sấm Trạng Trình">Sấm Trạng Trình</a></i>. The name has also been found on 12 <a href="/wiki/Stele" title="Stele">steles</a> carved in the 16th and 17th centuries, including one at Bao Lam Pagoda in <a href="/wiki/Haiphong" title="Haiphong">Hải Phòng</a> that dates to 1558.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPhan1976510_21-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPhan1976510-21">[16]</a></sup> In 1802, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_Ph%C3%BAc_%C3%81nh" title="Nguyễn Phúc Ánh">Nguyễn Phúc Ánh</a> (who later became Emperor Gia Long) established the <a href="/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_dynasty" title="Nguyễn dynasty">Nguyễn dynasty</a>. In the second year of his rule, he asked the <a href="/wiki/Jiaqing_Emperor" title="Jiaqing Emperor">Jiaqing Emperor</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Qing_dynasty" title="Qing dynasty">Qing dynasty</a> to confer on him the title 'King of Nam Việt / Nanyue' (<span title="Chinese-language text"><span lang="zh">南越</span></span> in Chinese character) after seizing power in Annam. The Emperor refused because the name was related to <a href="/wiki/Zhao_Tuo" title="Zhao Tuo">Zhao Tuo</a>'s Nanyue, which included the regions of <a href="/wiki/Guangxi" title="Guangxi">Guangxi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Guangdong" title="Guangdong">Guangdong</a> in southern China. The Qing Emperor, therefore, decided to call the area "Việt Nam" instead,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-etymology_23-0"><a href="#cite_note-etymology-23">[n 6]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOoi2004932_24-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOoi2004932-24">[18]</a></sup> meaning “South of the Viet” per <a href="/wiki/Classical_Chinese" title="Classical Chinese">Classical Chinese</a> word order but the Vietnamese understood it as “Viet of the South” per Vietnamese word order.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Brindley_2015_p27_14-1"><a href="#cite_note-Brindley_2015_p27-14">[9]</a></sup> Between 1804 and 1813, the name Vietnam was used officially by Emperor Gia Long.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-etymology_23-1"><a href="#cite_note-etymology-23">[n 6]</a></sup> It was revived in the early 20th century in <a href="/wiki/Phan_B%E1%BB%99i_Ch%C3%A2u" title="Phan Bội Châu">Phan Bội Châu</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Loss_of_Vietnam" title="History of the Loss of Vietnam">History of the Loss of Vietnam</a></i>, and later by the <a href="/wiki/Vi%E1%BB%87t_Nam_Qu%E1%BB%91c_D%C3%A2n_%C4%90%E1%BA%A3ng" title="Việt Nam Quốc Dân Đảng">Vietnamese Nationalist Party</a> (VNQDĐ).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETonnessonAntlov1996117_25-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETonnessonAntlov1996117-25">[19]</a></sup> The country was usually called Annam until 1945, when the <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_Vietnam" title="Empire of Vietnam">imperial government</a> in <a href="/wiki/Hu%E1%BA%BF" title="Huế">Huế</a> adopted <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi">Việt Nam</i></span>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETonnessonAntlov1996126_26-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETonnessonAntlov1996126-26">[20]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Vietnam" title="History of Vietnam">History of Vietnam</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">For a chronological guide, see <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Vietnamese_history" title="Timeline of Vietnamese history">Timeline of Vietnamese history</a>.</div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistory">Prehistory</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:DrumFromSongDaVietnamDongSonIICultureMid1stMilleniumBCEBronze.jpg"><img alt="Photograph of a Đông Sơn bronze drum" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1360" data-file-width="1680" decoding="async" height="178" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/DrumFromSongDaVietnamDongSonIICultureMid1stMilleniumBCEBronze.jpg/220px-DrumFromSongDaVietnamDongSonIICultureMid1stMilleniumBCEBronze.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/DrumFromSongDaVietnamDongSonIICultureMid1stMilleniumBCEBronze.jpg/330px-DrumFromSongDaVietnamDongSonIICultureMid1stMilleniumBCEBronze.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/DrumFromSongDaVietnamDongSonIICultureMid1stMilleniumBCEBronze.jpg/440px-DrumFromSongDaVietnamDongSonIICultureMid1stMilleniumBCEBronze.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:DrumFromSongDaVietnamDongSonIICultureMid1stMilleniumBCEBronze.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C4%90%C3%B4ng_S%C6%A1n_drums" title="Đông Sơn drums">Đông Sơn</a> bronze drum, <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 800 BC</span></div></div></div>
<p>Archaeological excavations have revealed the existence of humans in what is now Vietnam as early as the <a href="/wiki/Paleolithic" title="Paleolithic">Paleolithic</a> age. Stone artefacts excavated in <a href="/wiki/Gia_Lai_province" title="Gia Lai province">Gia Lai province</a> have been claimed to date to 0.78 Ma,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-27"><a href="#cite_note-27">[21]</a></sup> based on associated find of <a href="/wiki/Tektite" title="Tektite">tektites</a>, however this claim has been challenged because tektites are often found in archaeological sites of various ages in Vietnam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28"><a href="#cite_note-28">[22]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Homo_erectus" title="Homo erectus">Homo erectus</a></i> fossils dating to around 500,000 BC have been found in caves in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/L%E1%BA%A1ng_S%C6%A1n_Province" title="Lạng Sơn Province">Lạng Sơn</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ngh%E1%BB%87_An_Province" title="Nghệ An Province">Nghệ An</a> provinces in northern Vietnam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcKinney2009_29-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcKinney2009-29">[23]</a></sup> The oldest <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Homo_sapiens" title="Homo sapiens">Homo sapiens</a></i> fossils from mainland Southeast Asia are of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Middle_Pleistocene" title="Middle Pleistocene">Middle Pleistocene</a> provenance, and include isolated tooth fragments from Tham Om and Hang Hum.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAkazawaAokiKimura1992321_30-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAkazawaAokiKimura1992321-30">[24]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERabett2012109_31-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERabett2012109-31">[25]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDennellPorr201441_32-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDennellPorr201441-32">[26]</a></sup> Teeth attributed to <i>Homo sapiens</i> from the <a href="/wiki/Late_Pleistocene" title="Late Pleistocene">Late Pleistocene</a> have been found at Dong Can,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMatsumuraYonedaYukioOxenham200812_33-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMatsumuraYonedaYukioOxenham200812-33">[27]</a></sup> and from the Early <a href="/wiki/Holocene" title="Holocene">Holocene</a> at Mai Da Dieu,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMatsumuraLan_CuongKim_ThuyAnezaki2001_34-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMatsumuraLan_CuongKim_ThuyAnezaki2001-34">[28]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOxenhamTayles200636_35-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOxenhamTayles200636-35">[29]</a></sup> Lang Gao<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENguyen198516_36-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENguyen198516-36">[30]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKarlströmKällén200283_37-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKarlströmKällén200283-37">[31]</a></sup> and Lang Cuom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOxenhamBuckley2015329_38-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOxenhamBuckley2015329-38">[32]</a></sup> By about 1,000 BC, the development of wet-<a href="/wiki/Rice" title="Rice">rice</a> cultivation in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ma_River" title="Ma River">Ma River</a> and <a href="/wiki/Red_River_(Asia)" title="Red River (Asia)">Red River</a> floodplains led to the flourishing of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C4%90%C3%B4ng_S%C6%A1n_culture" title="Đông Sơn culture">Đông Sơn culture</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHigham1984_39-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHigham1984-39">[33]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENang_ChungGiang_Hai201731_40-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENang_ChungGiang_Hai201731-40">[34]</a></sup> notable for its <a href="/wiki/Bronze" title="Bronze">bronze</a> casting used to make elaborate bronze <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C4%90%C3%B4ng_S%C6%A1n_drums" title="Đông Sơn drums">Đông Sơn drums</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEde_LaetHerrmann1996408_41-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEde_LaetHerrmann1996408-41">[35]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECalò200951_42-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECalò200951-42">[36]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKiernan201731_43-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKiernan201731-43">[37]</a></sup> At this point, the early Vietnamese kingdoms of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/V%C4%83n_Lang" title="Văn Lang">Văn Lang</a> and <a href="/wiki/%C3%82u_L%E1%BA%A1c" title="Âu Lạc">Âu Lạc</a> appeared, and the culture's influence spread to other parts of <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a>, including <a href="/wiki/Maritime_Southeast_Asia" title="Maritime Southeast Asia">Maritime Southeast Asia</a>, throughout the first millennium BC.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECalò200951_42-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECalò200951-42">[36]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECookeLiAnderson201146_44-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECookeLiAnderson201146-44">[38]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Dynastic_Vietnam">Dynastic Vietnam</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">For a chronological guide, see <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Vietnam_under_Chinese_rule" title="Timeline of Vietnam under Chinese rule">Timeline of Vietnam under Chinese rule</a>.</div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Nguyen_Dynasty,_administrative_divisions_map_(1838).svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="835" data-file-width="595" decoding="async" height="309" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Nguyen_Dynasty%2C_administrative_divisions_map_%281838%29.svg/220px-Nguyen_Dynasty%2C_administrative_divisions_map_%281838%29.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Nguyen_Dynasty%2C_administrative_divisions_map_%281838%29.svg/330px-Nguyen_Dynasty%2C_administrative_divisions_map_%281838%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Nguyen_Dynasty%2C_administrative_divisions_map_%281838%29.svg/440px-Nguyen_Dynasty%2C_administrative_divisions_map_%281838%29.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Nguyen_Dynasty,_administrative_divisions_map_(1838).svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Vietnam's territories around 1838</div></div></div>
<p>According to legends, <a href="/wiki/H%E1%BB%93ng_B%C3%A0ng_dynasty" title="Hồng Bàng dynasty">Hồng Bàng dynasty</a> of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/H%C3%B9ng_kings" title="Hùng kings">Hùng kings</a> first established in 2879 BC is considered the first state in the <a href="/wiki/History_of_Vietnam" title="History of Vietnam">History of Vietnam</a> (then known as Xích Quỷ and later <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/V%C4%83n_Lang" title="Văn Lang">Văn Lang</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPelley2002151_45-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPelley2002151-45">[39]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECottrell200914_46-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECottrell200914-46">[40]</a></sup> In 257 BC, the last Hùng king was defeated by Thục Phán. He consolidated the <a href="/wiki/L%E1%BA%A1c_Vi%E1%BB%87t" title="Lạc Việt">Lạc Việt</a> and <a href="/wiki/%C3%82u_Vi%E1%BB%87t" title="Âu Việt">Âu Việt</a> tribes to form the <a href="/wiki/%C3%82u_L%E1%BA%A1c" title="Âu Lạc">Âu Lạc</a>, proclaiming himself <a href="/wiki/An_D%C6%B0%C6%A1ng_V%C6%B0%C6%A1ng" title="An Dương Vương">An Dương Vương</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEĐức_TrầnThư_Hà20008_47-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEĐức_TrầnThư_Hà20008-47">[41]</a></sup> In 179 BC, a Chinese general named <a href="/wiki/Zhao_Tuo" title="Zhao Tuo">Zhao Tuo</a> defeated An Dương Vương and consolidated Âu Lạc into <a href="/wiki/Nanyue" title="Nanyue">Nanyue</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENang_ChungGiang_Hai201731_40-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENang_ChungGiang_Hai201731-40">[34]</a></sup> However, Nanyue was itself <a href="/wiki/Southward_expansion_of_the_Han_dynasty" title="Southward expansion of the Han dynasty">incorporated into the empire</a> of the Chinese <a href="/wiki/Han_dynasty" title="Han dynasty">Han dynasty</a> in 111 BC after the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Han%E2%80%93Nanyue_War" title="Han–Nanyue War">Han–Nanyue War</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOoi2004932_24-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOoi2004932-24">[18]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEYao201662_48-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEYao201662-48">[42]</a></sup> For the next thousand years, what is now northern Vietnam remained mostly under <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chinese_domination_of_Vietnam" title="Chinese domination of Vietnam">Chinese rule</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHolmgren1980_49-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHolmgren1980-49">[43]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaylor198330_50-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaylor198330-50">[44]</a></sup> Early independence movements, such as those of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tr%C6%B0ng_Sisters" title="Trưng Sisters">Trưng Sisters</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lady_Tri%E1%BB%87u" title="Lady Triệu">Lady Triệu</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPelley2002177_51-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPelley2002177-51">[45]</a></sup> were temporarily successful,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECottrell200915_52-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECottrell200915-52">[46]</a></sup> though the region gained a longer period of independence as Vạn Xuân under the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anterior_L%C3%BD_dynasty" title="Anterior Lý dynasty">Anterior Lý dynasty</a> between AD 544 and 602.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThái_NguyênMừng_Nguyẽ̂n195833_53-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThái_NguyênMừng_Nguyẽ̂n195833-53">[47]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChesneaux196620_54-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChesneaux196620-54">[48]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEanon.197224_55-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEanon.197224-55">[49]</a></sup> By the early 10th century, Northern Vietnam had gained autonomy, but not sovereignty, under the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kh%C3%BAc_family" title="Khúc family">Khúc family</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETuyet_TranReid200632_56-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETuyet_TranReid200632-56">[50]</a></sup>
</p><p>In AD 938, the Vietnamese lord <a href="/wiki/Ng%C3%B4_Quy%E1%BB%81n" title="Ngô Quyền">Ngô Quyền</a> defeated the forces of the Chinese <a href="/wiki/Southern_Han" title="Southern Han">Southern Han</a> state at <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_B%E1%BA%A1ch_%C4%90%E1%BA%B1ng_(938)" title="Battle of Bạch Đằng (938)">Bạch Đằng River</a> and achieved full independence for Vietnam after a millennium of Chinese domination.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiẻ̂n_Lê200365_57-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiẻ̂n_Lê200365-57">[51]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHong_LienSharrock201455_58-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHong_LienSharrock201455-58">[52]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKiernan2017226_59-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKiernan2017226-59">[53]</a></sup> By the 960s, the dynastic <a href="/wiki/%C4%90%E1%BA%A1i_Vi%E1%BB%87t" title="Đại Việt">Đại Việt</a> (<i>Great Viet</i>) kingdom was established, Vietnamese society enjoyed a golden era under the Lý and <a href="/wiki/Tr%E1%BA%A7n_dynasty" title="Trần dynasty">Trần</a> dynasties. During the rule of the Trần Dynasty, Đại Việt repelled three <a href="/wiki/Mongol_invasions_of_Vietnam" title="Mongol invasions of Vietnam">Mongol invasions</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECottrell200916_60-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECottrell200916-60">[54]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHong_LienSharrock201495_61-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHong_LienSharrock201495-61">[55]</a></sup> Meanwhile, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mah%C4%81y%C4%81na" title="Mahāyāna">Mahāyāna</a> branch of <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Vietnam" title="Buddhism in Vietnam">Buddhism</a> flourished and became the state religion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKiernan2017226_59-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKiernan2017226-59">[53]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeyes1995183_62-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeyes1995183-62">[56]</a></sup> Following the 1406–7 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ming%E2%80%93H%E1%BB%93_War" title="Ming–Hồ War">Ming–Hồ War</a>, which overthrew the <a href="/wiki/H%E1%BB%93_dynasty" title="Hồ dynasty">Hồ dynasty</a>, Vietnamese independence was <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fourth_Chinese_domination_of_Vietnam" title="Fourth Chinese domination of Vietnam">interrupted briefly</a> by the Chinese <a href="/wiki/Ming_dynasty" title="Ming dynasty">Ming dynasty</a>, but was restored by <a href="/wiki/L%C3%AA_L%E1%BB%A3i" title="Lê Lợi">Lê Lợi</a>, the founder of the <a href="/wiki/L%C3%AA_dynasty" title="Lê dynasty">Lê dynasty</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHong_LienSharrock2014111_63-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHong_LienSharrock2014111-63">[57]</a></sup> The Vietnamese polity reached their zenith in the Lê dynasty of the 15th century, especially during the reign of king <a href="/wiki/L%C3%AA_Th%C3%A1nh_T%C3%B4ng" title="Lê Thánh Tông">Lê Thánh Tông</a> (1460–1497).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHong_LienSharrock2014120_64-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHong_LienSharrock2014120-64">[58]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKiernan2017265_65-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKiernan2017265-65">[59]</a></sup> Between the 11th and 18th centuries, the Vietnamese polity expanded southward in a gradual process known as <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi"><a href="/wiki/Nam_ti%E1%BA%BFn" title="Nam tiến">Nam tiến</a></i></span> ("Southward expansion"),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAndersonWhitmore2014158_66-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAndersonWhitmore2014158-66">[60]</a></sup> eventually conquering the kingdom of <a href="/wiki/Champa" title="Champa">Champa</a> and part of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Post-Angkor_Period" title="Post-Angkor Period">Khmer Kingdom</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVo201113_67-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVo201113-67">[61]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOoiAnh_Tuan2015212_68-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOoiAnh_Tuan2015212-68">[62]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPhuong_Linh201639_69-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPhuong_Linh201639-69">[63]</a></sup>
</p><p>From the 16th century onward, civil strife and frequent political infighting engulfed much of Dai Viet. First, the Chinese-supported <a href="/wiki/M%E1%BA%A1c_dynasty" title="Mạc dynasty">Mạc dynasty</a> challenged the Lê dynasty's power.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAndersonWhitmore2014174_70-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAndersonWhitmore2014174-70">[64]</a></sup> After the Mạc dynasty was defeated, the Lê dynasty was nominally reinstalled. Actual power, however, was divided between the northern <a href="/wiki/Tr%E1%BB%8Bnh_lords" title="Trịnh lords">Trịnh lords</a> and the southern <a href="/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_lords" title="Nguyễn lords">Nguyễn lords</a>, who engaged in a <a href="/wiki/Tr%E1%BB%8Bnh%E2%80%93Nguy%E1%BB%85n_War" title="Trịnh–Nguyễn War">civil war</a> for more than four decades before a truce was called in the 1670s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELeonard1984131_71-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELeonard1984131-71">[65]</a></sup> During this period, the Nguyễn expanded southern Vietnam into the <a href="/wiki/Mekong_Delta" title="Mekong Delta">Mekong Delta</a>, annexing the <a href="/wiki/Central_Highlands_(Vietnam)" title="Central Highlands (Vietnam)">Central Highlands</a> and the Khmer lands in the Mekong Delta.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVo201113_67-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVo201113-67">[61]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPhuong_Linh201639_69-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPhuong_Linh201639-69">[63]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOoi2004356_72-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOoi2004356-72">[66]</a></sup> The division of the country ended a century later when the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/T%C3%A2y_S%C6%A1n" title="Tây Sơn">Tây Sơn</a> brothers established a new dynasty. However, their rule did not last long, and they were defeated by the remnants of the Nguyễn lords, led by <a href="/wiki/Gia_Long" title="Gia Long">Nguyễn Ánh</a>, aided by the French.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPageSonnenburg2003723_73-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPageSonnenburg2003723-73">[67]</a></sup> Nguyễn Ánh unified Vietnam, and established the <a href="/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_dynasty" title="Nguyễn dynasty">Nguyễn dynasty</a>, ruling under the name <a href="/wiki/Gia_Long" title="Gia Long">Gia Long</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOoi2004356_72-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOoi2004356-72">[66]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="French_Indochina">French Indochina</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Cochinchina_campaign" title="Cochinchina campaign">Cochinchina campaign</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sino-French_War" title="Sino-French War">Sino-French War</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tonkin_campaign" title="Tonkin campaign">Tonkin campaign</a>, and <a href="/wiki/French_Indochina" title="French Indochina">French Indochina</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:ExpositionHanoi1902_GrandPalais_(1).jpg"><img alt="Photograph of the Grand Palais building in Hanoi" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="473" data-file-width="759" decoding="async" height="162" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/ExpositionHanoi1902_GrandPalais_%281%29.jpg/260px-ExpositionHanoi1902_GrandPalais_%281%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/ExpositionHanoi1902_GrandPalais_%281%29.jpg/390px-ExpositionHanoi1902_GrandPalais_%281%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/ExpositionHanoi1902_GrandPalais_%281%29.jpg/520px-ExpositionHanoi1902_GrandPalais_%281%29.jpg 2x" width="260"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:ExpositionHanoi1902_GrandPalais_(1).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Grand_Palais_(Hanoi)" title="Grand Palais (Hanoi)">Grand Palais</a> built for the 1902–1903 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hanoi_exhibition" title="Hanoi exhibition">world's fair</a>, when <a href="/wiki/Hanoi" title="Hanoi">Hanoi</a> was French Indochina's capital</div></div></div>
<p>In the 1500s, the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Empire" title="Portuguese Empire">Portuguese</a> explored the Vietnamese coast and reportedly erected a <a href="/wiki/Stele" title="Stele">stele</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Ch%C3%A0m_Islands" title="Chàm Islands">Chàm Islands</a> to mark their presence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHoàng200750_74-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHoàng200750-74">[68]</a></sup> By 1533, they began landing in the Vietnamese delta but were forced to leave because of local turmoil and fighting. They also had less interest in the territory than they did in China and Japan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHoàng200750_74-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHoàng200750-74">[68]</a></sup> After they had settled in <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Macau" title="Portuguese Macau">Macau</a> and <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Nagasaki" title="Portuguese Nagasaki">Nagasaki</a> to begin the profitable Macau–Japan trade route, the Portuguese began to involve themselves in trade with <a href="/wiki/H%E1%BB%99i_An" title="Hội An">Hội An</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHoàng200750_74-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHoàng200750-74">[68]</a></sup> Portuguese traders and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Society_of_Jesus" title="Society of Jesus">Jesuit</a> missionaries under the <i><a href="/wiki/Padroado" title="Padroado">Padroado</a></i> system were active in both Vietnamese realms of <i><a href="/wiki/%C4%90%C3%A0ng_Trong" title="Đàng Trong">Đàng Trong</a></i> (<a href="/wiki/Cochinchina" title="Cochinchina">Cochinchina</a> or Quinan) and <i><a href="/wiki/%C4%90%C3%A0ng_Ngo%C3%A0i" title="Đàng Ngoài">Đàng Ngoài</a></i> (<a href="/wiki/Tonkin" title="Tonkin">Tonkin</a>) in the 17th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETran2018_75-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETran2018-75">[69]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Dutch_Empire" title="Dutch Empire">Dutch</a> also tried to establish contact with Quinan in 1601 but failed to sustain a presence there after several violent encounters with the locals. The <a href="/wiki/Dutch_East_India_Company" title="Dutch East India Company">Dutch East India Company</a> (VOC) only managed to establish official relations with Tonkin in the spring of 1637 after leaving <a href="/wiki/Dejima" title="Dejima">Dejima</a> in Japan to establish trade for <a href="/wiki/Silk" title="Silk">silk</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHoàng200752_76-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHoàng200752-76">[70]</a></sup> Meanwhile, in 1613, the first <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_England" title="Kingdom of England">English</a> attempt to establish contact with Hội An failed following a violent incident involving the <a href="/wiki/East_India_Company" title="East India Company">Honourable East India Company</a>. By 1672 the English did establish relations with Tonkin and were allowed to reside in <a href="/wiki/H%C6%B0ng_Y%C3%AAn" title="Hưng Yên">Phố Hiến</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHoàng200753_77-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHoàng200753-77">[71]</a></sup>
</p><p>Between 1615 and 1753, <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">French</a> traders also engaged in trade in Vietnam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELi199889_78-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELi199889-78">[72]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELockard2010479_79-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELockard2010479-79">[73]</a></sup> The first French missionaries arrived in 1658, under the Portuguese <i>Padroado</i>. From its foundation, the <a href="/wiki/Paris_Foreign_Missions_Society" title="Paris Foreign Missions Society">Paris Foreign Missions Society</a> under <a href="/wiki/Congregation_for_the_Evangelization_of_Peoples" title="Congregation for the Evangelization of Peoples"><i>Propaganda Fide</i></a> actively sent missionaries to Vietnam, entering Cochinchina first in 1664 and Tonkin first in 1666.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETran201727_80-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETran201727-80">[74]</a></sup> Spanish <a href="/wiki/Dominican_Order" title="Dominican Order">Dominicans</a> joined the Tonkin mission in 1676, and <a href="/wiki/Franciscans" title="Franciscans">Franciscans</a> were in Cochinchina from 1719 to 1834. The Vietnamese authorities began<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers"><span title="The time period mentioned near this tag is ambiguous. (October 2020)">when?</span></a></i>]</sup> to feel threatened by continuous <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Christianisation" title="Christianisation">Christianisation</a> activities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcLeod199122_81-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcLeod199122-81">[75]</a></sup> After several Catholic missionaries were detained, the <a href="/wiki/French_Navy" title="French Navy">French Navy</a> intervened in 1843 to free them, as the kingdom was perceived as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Xenophobic" title="Xenophobic">xenophobic</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWoods200242_82-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWoods200242-82">[76]</a></sup> In a series of conquests from 1859 to 1885, <a href="/wiki/French_colonial_empire" title="French colonial empire">France eroded</a> Vietnam's sovereignty.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECortada199429_83-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECortada199429-83">[77]</a></sup> At the <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Tourane" title="Siege of Tourane">Siege of Tourane</a> in 1858, France was aided by <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Empire" title="Spanish Empire">Spain</a> (with Filipino, <a href="/wiki/Latin_American_Asian" title="Latin American Asian">Latin American</a>, and Spanish troops from the <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a>)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84"><a href="#cite_note-84">[78]</a></sup> and perhaps some Tonkinese Catholics.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeith201246_85-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeith201246-85">[79]</a></sup> After the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Saigon_(1862)" title="Treaty of Saigon (1862)">1862 Treaty</a>, and especially after France completely conquered <a href="/wiki/Southern_Vietnam" title="Southern Vietnam">Lower Cochinchina</a> in 1867, the <a href="/wiki/V%C4%83n_Th%C3%A2n_movement" title="Văn Thân movement">Văn Thân movement</a> of scholar-gentry class arose and committed violence against <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Catholic" title="Catholic">Catholics</a> across central and northern Vietnam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeith201249–50_86-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeith201249–50-86">[80]</a></sup>
</p><p>Between 1862 and 1867, the southern third of the country became the <a href="/wiki/French_Cochinchina" title="French Cochinchina">French colony of Cochinchina</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcLeod199161_87-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcLeod199161-87">[81]</a></sup> By 1884, the entire country was under French rule, with the central and northern parts of Vietnam separated into the two protectorates of <a href="/wiki/Annam_(French_protectorate)" title="Annam (French protectorate)">Annam</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tonkin_(French_protectorate)" title="Tonkin (French protectorate)">Tonkin</a>. The three entities were formally integrated into the union of <a href="/wiki/French_Indochina" title="French Indochina">French Indochina</a> in 1887.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOoi2004520_88-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOoi2004520-88">[82]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECook2001396_89-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECook2001396-89">[83]</a></sup> The French administration imposed significant political and cultural changes on Vietnamese society.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFrankum2011172_90-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFrankum2011172-90">[84]</a></sup> A Western-style system of modern education introduced new <a href="/wiki/Humanism" title="Humanism">humanist</a> values.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENhu_Nguyen201637_91-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENhu_Nguyen201637-91">[85]</a></sup> Most French settlers in Indochina were concentrated in Cochinchina, particularly in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Saigon" title="Saigon">Saigon</a>, and in <a href="/wiki/Hanoi" title="Hanoi">Hanoi</a>, the colony's capital.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERichardson1876269_92-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERichardson1876269-92">[86]</a></sup>
</p><p>During the colonial period, guerrillas of the royalist <a href="/wiki/C%E1%BA%A7n_V%C6%B0%C6%A1ng_movement" title="Cần Vương movement">Cần Vương movement</a> rebelled against French rule and massacred around a third of <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_Vietnam" title="Christianity in Vietnam">Vietnam's Christian</a> population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeith201253_93-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeith201253-93">[87]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAnh_Ngo201671_94-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAnh_Ngo201671-94">[88]</a></sup> After a decade of resistance, they were defeated in the 1890s by the Catholics in reprisal for their earlier massacres.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEQuach_Langlet1991360_95-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEQuach_Langlet1991360-95">[89]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERamsay2008171_96-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERamsay2008171-96">[90]</a></sup> Another large-scale rebellion, the <a href="/wiki/Th%C3%A1i_Nguy%C3%AAn_uprising" title="Thái Nguyên uprising">Thái Nguyên uprising</a>, was also suppressed heavily.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEZinoman2000_97-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEZinoman2000-97">[91]</a></sup> The French developed a <a href="/wiki/Plantation_economy" title="Plantation economy">plantation economy</a> to promote export of <a href="/wiki/Tobacco" title="Tobacco">tobacco</a>, <a href="/wiki/Indigo_dye" title="Indigo dye">indigo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tea" title="Tea">tea</a> and <a href="/wiki/Coffee" title="Coffee">coffee</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELim201433_98-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELim201433-98">[92]</a></sup> However, they largely ignored the increasing demands for civil rights and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Self-government" title="Self-government">self-government</a>.
</p><p>A nationalist political movement soon emerged, with leaders like <a href="/wiki/Phan_B%E1%BB%99i_Ch%C3%A2u" title="Phan Bội Châu">Phan Bội Châu</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Phan_Ch%C3%A2u_Trinh" title="Phan Châu Trinh">Phan Châu Trinh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Phan_%C4%90%C3%ACnh_Ph%C3%B9ng" title="Phan Đình Phùng">Phan Đình Phùng</a>, Emperor <a href="/wiki/H%C3%A0m_Nghi" title="Hàm Nghi">Hàm Nghi</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/H%E1%BB%93_Ch%C3%AD_Minh" title="Hồ Chí Minh">Hồ Chí Minh</a> fighting or calling for independence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELargo2002112_99-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELargo2002112-99">[93]</a></sup> This resulted in the 1930 <a href="/wiki/Y%C3%AAn_B%C3%A1i_mutiny" title="Yên Bái mutiny">Yên Bái mutiny</a> by the <a href="/wiki/Vi%E1%BB%87t_Nam_Qu%E1%BB%91c_D%C3%A2n_%C4%90%E1%BA%A3ng" title="Việt Nam Quốc Dân Đảng">Vietnamese Nationalist Party</a> (VNQDĐ), which the French quashed. The mutiny split the independence movement, as many leading members converted to <a href="/wiki/Communism" title="Communism">communism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhánh_Huỳnh198698_100-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhánh_Huỳnh198698-100">[94]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOdellCastillo200882_101-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOdellCastillo200882-101">[95]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThomas2012_102-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThomas2012-102">[96]</a></sup>
</p><p>The French maintained full control of their colonies until World War II, when the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_War" title="Pacific War">war in the Pacific</a> led to the <a href="/wiki/Japanese_invasion_of_French_Indochina" title="Japanese invasion of French Indochina">Japanese invasion of French Indochina</a> in 1940. Afterwards, the <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_Japan" title="Empire of Japan">Japanese Empire</a> was allowed to station its troops in Vietnam while the pro-<a href="/wiki/Vichy_France" title="Vichy France">Vichy French</a> colonial administration continued.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiller1990293_103-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiller1990293-103">[97]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGettlemanFranklinYoungFranklin19954_104-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGettlemanFranklinYoungFranklin19954-104">[98]</a></sup> Japan exploited Vietnam's natural resources to support its military campaigns, culminating in a <a href="/wiki/Japanese_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat_in_French_Indochina" title="Japanese coup d'état in French Indochina">full-scale takeover of the country</a> in March 1945. This led to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vietnamese_Famine_of_1945" title="Vietnamese Famine of 1945">Vietnamese Famine of 1945</a> which killed up to two million people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThanh_Niên2015_105-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThanh_Niên2015-105">[99]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Net2015_106-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Net2015-106">[100]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="First_Indochina_War">First Indochina War</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/First_Indochina_War" title="First Indochina War">First Indochina War</a>, <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_Vietnam" title="Empire of Vietnam">Empire of Vietnam</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Democratic_Republic_of_Vietnam" title="Democratic Republic of Vietnam">Democratic Republic of Vietnam</a>, <a href="/wiki/State_of_Vietnam" title="State of Vietnam">State of Vietnam</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Operation_Passage_to_Freedom" title="Operation Passage to Freedom">Operation Passage to Freedom</a></div>
<p>In 1941, the <a href="/wiki/Viet_Minh" title="Viet Minh">Việt Minh</a>, a nationalist liberation movement based on a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Communist_Ideology" title="Communist Ideology">Communist Ideology</a>, emerged under the Vietnamese revolutionary leader <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/H%E1%BB%93_Ch%C3%AD_Minh" title="Hồ Chí Minh">Hồ Chí Minh</a>. The Việt Minh sought independence for Vietnam from France and the end of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Japanese_occupation_of_Vietnam" title="Japanese occupation of Vietnam">Japanese occupation</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJoes199295_107-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJoes199295-107">[101]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPike2011192_108-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPike2011192-108">[102]</a></sup> After the military defeat of Japan and the fall of its puppet <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_Vietnam" title="Empire of Vietnam">Empire of Vietnam</a> in August 1945, Saigon's administrative services collapsed and chaos, riots, and murder were widespread.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGunn2014270_109-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGunn2014270-109">[103]</a></sup> The Việt Minh occupied <a href="/wiki/Hanoi" title="Hanoi">Hanoi</a> and proclaimed a provisional government, which asserted national independence on 2 September.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPike2011192_108-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPike2011192-108">[102]</a></sup>
</p><p>In July 1945, the <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II" title="Allies of World War II">Allies</a> had decided to divide Indochina at the <a href="/wiki/16th_parallel_north" title="16th parallel north">16th parallel</a> to allow <a href="/wiki/Chiang_Kai-shek" title="Chiang Kai-shek">Chiang Kai-shek</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_China_(1912%E2%80%931949)" title="Republic of China (1912–1949)">Republic of China</a> to receive the Japanese surrender in the north while Britain's <a href="/wiki/Louis_Mountbatten,_1st_Earl_Mountbatten_of_Burma" title="Louis Mountbatten, 1st Earl Mountbatten of Burma">Lord Louis Mountbatten</a> received their surrender in the south. The Allies agreed that Indochina still belonged to France.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENeville2007175_110-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENeville2007175-110">[104]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESmith20076_111-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESmith20076-111">[105]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:French_Indochina_post_partition.png"><img alt="Map showing the partition of French Indochina following the 1954 Geneva Conference" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="457" data-file-width="300" decoding="async" height="335" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/French_Indochina_post_partition.png/220px-French_Indochina_post_partition.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/60/French_Indochina_post_partition.png 1.5x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:French_Indochina_post_partition.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Partition_(politics)" title="Partition (politics)">Partition</a> of French Indochina after the <a href="/wiki/1954_Geneva_Conference" title="1954 Geneva Conference">1954 Geneva Conference</a></div></div></div>
<p>But as the French were weakened by the <a href="/wiki/German_military_administration_in_occupied_France_during_World_War_II" title="German military administration in occupied France during World War II">German occupation</a>, <a href="/wiki/British_Raj" title="British Raj">British-Indian</a> forces and the remaining Japanese <a href="/wiki/Southern_Expeditionary_Army_Group" title="Southern Expeditionary Army Group">Southern Expeditionary Army Group</a> were used to maintain order and help France reestablish control through the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/War_in_Vietnam_(1945%E2%80%9346)" title="War in Vietnam (1945–46)">1945–1946 War in Vietnam</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENeville2007124_112-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENeville2007124-112">[106]</a></sup> Hồ initially chose to take a moderate stance to avoid military conflict with France, asking the French to withdraw their colonial administrators and for French professors and engineers to help build a modern independent Vietnam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPike2011192_108-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPike2011192-108">[102]</a></sup> But the <a href="/wiki/Provisional_Government_of_the_French_Republic" title="Provisional Government of the French Republic">Provisional Government of the French Republic</a> did not act on these requests, including the idea of independence, and dispatched the <a href="/wiki/French_Far_East_Expeditionary_Corps" title="French Far East Expeditionary Corps">French Far East Expeditionary Corps</a> to restore colonial rule. This resulted in the Việt Minh launching a guerrilla campaign against the French in late 1946.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJoes199295_107-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJoes199295-107">[101]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPike2011192_108-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPike2011192-108">[102]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETonnesson201166_113-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETonnesson201166-113">[107]</a></sup> The resulting <a href="/wiki/First_Indochina_War" title="First Indochina War">First Indochina War</a> lasted until July 1954. The defeat of French colonialists and <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_National_Army" title="Vietnamese National Army">Vietnamese loyalists</a> in the 1954 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Battle_of_%C4%90i%E1%BB%87n_Bi%C3%AAn_Ph%E1%BB%A7" title="Battle of Điện Biên Phủ">battle of Điện Biên Phủ</a> allowed Hồ to negotiate a ceasefire from a favourable position at the subsequent <a href="/wiki/1954_Geneva_Conference" title="1954 Geneva Conference">Geneva Conference</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPike2011192_108-4"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPike2011192-108">[102]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWaite201289_114-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWaite201289-114">[108]</a></sup>
</p><p>The colonial administration was thereby ended and French Indochina was dissolved under the Geneva Accords of 1954 into three countries—Vietnam, and the kingdoms of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Cambodia_(1953%E2%80%931970)" title="Kingdom of Cambodia (1953–1970)">Cambodia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Laos" title="Kingdom of Laos">Laos</a>. Vietnam was further divided into North and South administrative regions at the <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_Demilitarized_Zone" title="Vietnamese Demilitarized Zone">Demilitarised Zone</a>, roughly along the <a href="/wiki/17th_parallel_north" title="17th parallel north">17th parallel north</a>, pending elections scheduled for July 1956.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119"><a href="#cite_note-119">[n 7]</a></sup> A 300-day period of free movement was permitted, during which almost a million northerners, mainly Catholics, moved south, fearing persecution by the communists. This migration was in large part aided by the United States military through <a href="/wiki/Operation_Passage_to_Freedom" title="Operation Passage to Freedom">Operation Passage to Freedom</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOlson201243_120-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOlson201243-120">[113]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDK201739_121-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDK201739-121">[114]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Partition_of_Vietnam" title="Partition of Vietnam">partition of Vietnam</a> by the Geneva Accords was not intended to be permanent, and stipulated that Vietnam would be reunited after the elections.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEvan_DijkGraySavranskayaSuri201368_122-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEvan_DijkGraySavranskayaSuri201368-122">[115]</a></sup> But in 1955, the southern State of Vietnam's prime minister, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ng%C3%B4_%C4%90%C3%ACnh_Di%E1%BB%87m" title="Ngô Đình Diệm">Ngô Đình Diệm</a>, toppled <a href="/wiki/B%E1%BA%A3o_%C4%90%E1%BA%A1i" title="Bảo Đại">Bảo Đại</a> in a fraudulent <a href="/wiki/1955_State_of_Vietnam_referendum" title="1955 State of Vietnam referendum">referendum</a> organised by his brother <a href="/wiki/Ng%C3%B4_%C4%90%C3%ACnh_Nhu" title="Ngô Đình Nhu">Ngô Đình Nhu</a>, and proclaimed himself president of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Republic_of_Vietnam" title="Republic of Vietnam">Republic of Vietnam</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEvan_DijkGraySavranskayaSuri201368_122-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEvan_DijkGraySavranskayaSuri201368-122">[115]</a></sup> This effectively replaced the internationally recognised <a href="/wiki/State_of_Vietnam" title="State of Vietnam">State of Vietnam</a> by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Republic_of_Vietnam" title="Republic of Vietnam">Republic of Vietnam</a> in the south—supported by the United States, France, <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Laos" title="Kingdom of Laos">Laos</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Republic_of_China" title="Republic of China">Republic of China</a> and Thailand—and Hồ's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Democratic_Republic_of_Vietnam" title="Democratic Republic of Vietnam">Democratic Republic of Vietnam</a> in the north, supported by the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a>, Sweden,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123"><a href="#cite_note-123">[116]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Khmer_Rouge" title="Khmer Rouge">Khmer Rouge</a>, and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="People's Republic of China">People's Republic of China</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEvan_DijkGraySavranskayaSuri201368_122-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEvan_DijkGraySavranskayaSuri201368-122">[115]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Vietnam_War">Vietnam War</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_War" title="Vietnam War">Vietnam War</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Role_of_the_United_States_in_the_Vietnam_War" title="Role of the United States in the Vietnam War">Role of the United States in the Vietnam War</a></div>
<p>From 1953 to 1956, the <a href="/wiki/North_Vietnam" title="North Vietnam">North Vietnamese</a> government instituted <a href="/wiki/Agrarianism" title="Agrarianism">agrarian</a> reforms including "<a href="/wiki/Rent_regulation" title="Rent regulation">rent reduction</a>" and "<a href="/wiki/Land_reform_in_Vietnam" title="Land reform in Vietnam">land reform</a>", which resulted in significant <a href="/wiki/Political_repression" title="Political repression">political repression</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMoïse201756_124-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMoïse201756-124">[117]</a></sup> During the land reform, testimony from North Vietnamese witnesses initially suggested a ratio of one execution for every 160 village residents, which extrapolated across all of Vietnam would indicate nearly 100,000 executions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETurner1975143_125-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETurner1975143-125">[118]</a></sup> Because the campaign was concentrated mainly in the <a href="/wiki/Red_River_Delta" title="Red River Delta">Red River Delta</a> area, a lower estimate of 50,000 executions became widely accepted by scholars at the time,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETurner1975143_125-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETurner1975143-125">[118]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGittinger1959_126-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGittinger1959-126">[119]</a></sup> but declassified documents from the Vietnamese and Hungarian archives indicate that the number was much lower, although likely more than 13,500.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVu2007_127-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVu2007-127">[120]</a></sup> In the South, Diệm countered North Vietnamese subversion (including the assassination of over 450 South Vietnamese officials in 1956) by detaining tens of thousands of suspected communists in "political reeducation centres".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHeneghan1969160_128-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHeneghan1969160-128">[121]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETurner1975177_129-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETurner1975177-129">[122]</a></sup> This program incarcerated many non-communists, but was successful at curtailing <a href="/wiki/Communism" title="Communism">communist</a> activity in the country, if only for a time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrozier1955_130-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrozier1955-130">[123]</a></sup> The North Vietnamese government claimed that 2,148 people were killed in the process by November 1957.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETurner1975174–178_131-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETurner1975174–178-131">[124]</a></sup> The pro-Hanoi <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vi%E1%BB%87t_C%E1%BB%99ng" title="Việt Cộng">Việt Cộng</a> began a guerrilla campaign in <a href="/wiki/South_Vietnam" title="South Vietnam">South Vietnam</a> in the late 1950s to overthrow Diệm's government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGilbert2013292_132-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGilbert2013292-132">[125]</a></sup> From 1960, the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a> and North Vietnam signed treaties providing for further Soviet military support.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJukes1973209_133-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJukes1973209-133">[126]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOlsen200792_134-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOlsen200792-134">[127]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhoo201127_135-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhoo201127-135">[128]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Agent_Orange_Cropdusting.jpg"><img alt="Three US Fairchild UC-123B aircraft pictured spraying Agent Orange" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="480" data-file-width="509" decoding="async" height="207" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Agent_Orange_Cropdusting.jpg/220px-Agent_Orange_Cropdusting.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Agent_Orange_Cropdusting.jpg/330px-Agent_Orange_Cropdusting.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Agent_Orange_Cropdusting.jpg/440px-Agent_Orange_Cropdusting.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Agent_Orange_Cropdusting.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Three US <a href="/wiki/Fairchild_C-123_Provider" title="Fairchild C-123 Provider">Fairchild UC-123B</a> aircraft spraying <a href="/wiki/Agent_Orange" title="Agent Orange">Agent Orange</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Operation_Ranch_Hand" title="Operation Ranch Hand">Operation Ranch Hand</a> as part of a <a href="/wiki/Herbicidal_warfare" title="Herbicidal warfare">herbicidal warfare</a> operation depriving the food and vegetation cover of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vi%E1%BB%87t_C%E1%BB%99ng" title="Việt Cộng">Việt Cộng</a>, <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 1962–1971</span></div></div></div>
<p>In 1963, Buddhist discontent with Diệm's Catholic regime erupted into <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_crisis" title="Buddhist crisis">mass demonstrations</a>, leading to a violent government crackdown.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMuehlenbeckMuehlenbeck2012221_136-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMuehlenbeckMuehlenbeck2012221-136">[129]</a></sup> This led to the <a href="/wiki/Cable_243" title="Cable 243">collapse of Diệm's relationship with the United States</a>, and ultimately to a <a href="/wiki/1963_South_Vietnamese_coup" title="1963 South Vietnamese coup">1963 coup</a> in which <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arrest_and_assassination_of_Ng%C3%B4_%C4%90%C3%ACnh_Di%E1%BB%87m" title="Arrest and assassination of Ngô Đình Diệm">he and Nhu were assassinated</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWillbanks201353_137-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWillbanks201353-137">[130]</a></sup> The Diệm era was followed by more than a dozen successive military governments, before the pairing of Air Marshal <a href="/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_Cao_K%E1%BB%B3" title="Nguyễn Cao Kỳ">Nguyễn Cao Kỳ</a> and General <a href="/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_V%C4%83n_Thi%E1%BB%87u" title="Nguyễn Văn Thiệu">Nguyễn Văn Thiệu</a> took control in mid-1965.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDuy_HinhDinh_Tho2015238_138-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDuy_HinhDinh_Tho2015238-138">[131]</a></sup> Thiệu gradually outmaneuvered Kỳ and cemented his grip on power in fraudulent elections in 1967 and 1971.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEIssermanBowman200946_139-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEIssermanBowman200946-139">[132]</a></sup> During this political instability, the communists began to gain ground. To support South Vietnam's struggle against the communist insurgency, the United States began increasing its contribution of military advisers, using the 1964 <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Tonkin_incident" title="Gulf of Tonkin incident">Gulf of Tonkin incident</a> as a pretext for such intervention.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAlterman2005213_140-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAlterman2005213-140">[133]</a></sup> US forces became involved in ground combat operations by 1965, and at their peak several years later, numbered more than 500,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewy1980_141-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewy1980-141">[134]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGibbons2014166_142-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGibbons2014166-142">[135]</a></sup> The US also engaged in <a href="/wiki/Operation_Rolling_Thunder" title="Operation Rolling Thunder">sustained aerial bombing</a>. Meanwhile, <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a> and the Soviet Union provided North Vietnam with significant material aid and 15,000 combat advisers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJukes1973209_133-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJukes1973209-133">[126]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOlsen200792_134-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOlsen200792-134">[127]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELi201267_143-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELi201267-143">[136]</a></sup> Communist forces supplying the Việt Cộng carried supplies along the <a href="/wiki/Ho_Chi_Minh_trail" title="Ho Chi Minh trail">Hồ Chí Minh trail</a>, which passed through <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Laos" title="Kingdom of Laos">Laos</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGillet2011_144-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGillet2011-144">[137]</a></sup>
</p><p>The communists attacked South Vietnamese targets during the 1968 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/T%E1%BA%BFt_Offensive" title="Tết Offensive">Tết Offensive</a>. The campaign failed militarily, but shocked the American establishment and turned US public opinion against the war.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDallek2018_145-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDallek2018-145">[138]</a></sup> During the offensive, communist troops <a href="/wiki/Massacre_at_Hu%E1%BA%BF" title="Massacre at Huế">massacred over 3,000 civilians</a> at <a href="/wiki/Hu%E1%BA%BF" title="Huế">Huế</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETurner1975251_146-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETurner1975251-146">[139]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFrankum2011209_147-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFrankum2011209-147">[140]</a></sup> Facing an increasing casualty count, <a href="/wiki/Opposition_to_United_States_involvement_in_the_Vietnam_War" title="Opposition to United States involvement in the Vietnam War">rising domestic opposition</a> to the war, and growing international condemnation, the US began <a href="/wiki/Nixon_Doctrine" title="Nixon Doctrine">withdrawing from ground combat roles</a> in the early 1970s.
