This also entailed an unsuccessful effort to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vietnamisation" title="Vietnamisation">strengthen and stabilise South Vietnam</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEggleston20141_148-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEggleston20141-148">[141]</a></sup> Following the <a href="/wiki/Paris_Peace_Accords" title="Paris Peace Accords">Paris Peace Accords</a> of 27 January 1973, all American combat troops were withdrawn by 29 March 1973.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHistory2018_149-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHistory2018-149">[142]</a></sup> In December 1974, North Vietnam <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Ph%C6%B0%E1%BB%9Bc_Long" title="Battle of Phước Long">captured</a> the province of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ph%C6%B0%E1%BB%9Bc_Long_Province" title="Phước Long Province">Phước Long</a> and started a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1975_Spring_Offensive" title="1975 Spring Offensive">full-scale offensive</a>, culminating in the <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_Saigon" title="Fall of Saigon">fall of Saigon</a> on 30 April 1975.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETucker2011749_150-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETucker2011749-150">[143]</a></sup> South Vietnam was ruled by a <a href="/wiki/Provisional_Revolutionary_Government_of_the_Republic_of_South_Vietnam" title="Provisional Revolutionary Government of the Republic of South Vietnam">provisional government</a> for almost eight years while under North Vietnamese military occupation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrigham199886_151-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrigham199886-151">[144]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Reunification_and_reforms">Reunification and reforms</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Re-education_camp_(Vietnam)" title="Re-education camp (Vietnam)">Re-education camp (Vietnam)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_boat_people" title="Vietnamese boat people">Vietnamese boat people</a>, and <a href="/wiki/%C4%90%E1%BB%95i_M%E1%BB%9Bi" title="Đổi Mới">Đổi Mới</a></div>
<p>On 2 July 1976, North and South Vietnam were merged to form the Socialist Republic of Việt Nam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE''The_New_York_Times''1976_152-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE''The_New_York_Times''1976-152">[145]</a></sup> The war devastated Vietnam and killed 966,000 to 3.8 million people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHirschmanPrestonManh_Loi1995_153-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHirschmanPrestonManh_Loi1995-153">[146]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEShenon1995_154-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEShenon1995-154">[147]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEObermeyerMurrayGakidou2008_155-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEObermeyerMurrayGakidou2008-155">[148]</a></sup> A 1974 US Senate subcommittee estimated nearly 1.4 million <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_War_casualties" title="Vietnam War casualties">Vietnamese civilians</a> were killed or wounded between 1965 and 1974—including 415,000 killed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDohrenwendTurseWallYager201869_156-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDohrenwendTurseWallYager201869-156">[149]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157"><a href="#cite_note-157">[150]</a></sup> In its aftermath, under <a href="/wiki/L%C3%AA_Du%E1%BA%A9n" title="Lê Duẩn">Lê Duẩn</a>'s administration, there were no mass executions of South Vietnamese who had collaborated with the US or the defunct South Vietnamese government, confounding Western fears,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEElliott2010499,_512–513_158-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEElliott2010499,_512–513-158">[151]</a></sup> but up to 300,000 South Vietnamese were sent to <a href="/wiki/Re-education_camp_(Vietnam)" title="Re-education camp (Vietnam)">reeducation camps</a>, where many endured torture, starvation, and disease while being forced to perform hard labour.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESaganDenny1982_159-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESaganDenny1982-159">[152]</a></sup> The government embarked on a mass campaign of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Collectivisation" title="Collectivisation">collectivisation</a> of farms and factories.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE''Spokesman-Review''19778_160-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE''Spokesman-Review''19778-160">[153]</a></sup> Many fled the country following the conclusion of the war.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMoise198812_161-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMoise198812-161">[154]</a></sup> In 1978, in response to the <a href="/wiki/Khmer_Rouge" title="Khmer Rouge">Khmer Rouge</a> government of Cambodia ordering massacres of Vietnamese residents in the border villages in the districts of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/An_Giang_Province" title="An Giang Province">An Giang</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ki%C3%AAn_Giang_Province" title="Kiên Giang Province">Kiên Giang</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKissi2006144_162-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKissi2006144-162">[155]</a></sup> the Vietnamese military <a href="/wiki/Cambodian%E2%80%93Vietnamese_War" title="Cambodian–Vietnamese War">invaded Cambodia</a> and removed them from power after occupying <a href="/wiki/Phnom_Penh" title="Phnom Penh">Phnom Penh</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMeggle2004166_163-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMeggle2004166-163">[156]</a></sup> The intervention was a success, resulting in the establishment of a new, pro-Vietnam socialist government, the <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Republic_of_Kampuchea" title="People's Republic of Kampuchea">People's Republic of Kampuchea</a>, which ruled until 1989.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHampson1996175_164-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHampson1996175-164">[157]</a></sup> However, this worsened relations with China, which had supported the Khmer Rouge. China later launched a <a href="/wiki/Sino-Vietnamese_War" title="Sino-Vietnamese War">brief incursion into northern Vietnam</a> in 1979, causing Vietnam to rely even more heavily on Soviet economic and military aid, while mistrust of the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_China" title="Government of China">Chinese government</a> escalated.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhoo2011131_165-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhoo2011131-165">[158]</a></sup>
</p><p>At the <a href="/wiki/6th_National_Congress_of_the_Communist_Party_of_Vietnam" title="6th National Congress of the Communist Party of Vietnam">Sixth National Congress</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Vietnam" title="Communist Party of Vietnam">Communist Party of Vietnam</a> (CPV) in December 1986, reformist politicians replaced the "old guard" government with new leadership.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBBC_News1997_166-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBBC_News1997-166">[159]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVăn_Phúc2014_167-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVăn_Phúc2014-167">[160]</a></sup> The reformers were led by 71-year-old <a href="/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_V%C4%83n_Linh" title="Nguyễn Văn Linh">Nguyễn Văn Linh</a>, who became the party's new general secretary.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBBC_News1997_166-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBBC_News1997-166">[159]</a></sup> He and the reformers implemented a series of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Free-market" title="Free-market">free-market</a> reforms known as <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi"><a href="/wiki/%C4%90%E1%BB%95i_M%E1%BB%9Bi" title="Đổi Mới">Đổi Mới</a></i></span> ("Renovation") that carefully managed the transition from a <a href="/wiki/Planned_economy" title="Planned economy">planned economy</a> to a "<a href="/wiki/Socialist-oriented_market_economy" title="Socialist-oriented market economy">socialist-oriented market economy</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMurray199724–25_168-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMurray199724–25-168">[161]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBich_Loan2007_169-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBich_Loan2007-169">[162]</a></sup> Although the authority of the state remained unchallenged under <i>Đổi Mới</i>, the government encouraged <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Private_ownership" title="Private ownership">private ownership</a> of farms and factories, economic deregulation, and foreign investment, while maintaining control over strategic industries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBich_Loan2007_169-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBich_Loan2007-169">[162]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHowe201620_170-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHowe201620-170">[163]</a></sup> Subsequently, Vietnam's economy achieved strong growth in agricultural and industrial production, construction, exports, and foreign investment, although these reforms also resulted in a rise in income inequality and gender disparities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGoodkind1995_171-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGoodkind1995-171">[164]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGallup2002_172-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGallup2002-172">[165]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWagstaffvan_DoorslaerWatanabe2003_173-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWagstaffvan_DoorslaerWatanabe2003-173">[166]</a></sup>
</p><p>
According to British journalist <a href="/wiki/Nick_Davies" title="Nick Davies">Nick Davies</a>, writing for <i><a href="/wiki/The_Guardian" title="The Guardian">The Guardian</a></i>, the long wars against the French and Americans have failed to achieve their stated goals:</p><blockquote><p>The reality now is that it has ended up with the worst of two systems: the authoritarian socialist state and the unfettered ideology of neoliberalism; the two combining to strip Vietnam’s people of their money and their rights while a tiny elite fills its pockets and hides behind the rhetoric of the revolution. That, finally, is the biggest lie of all. Victorious in war but defeated in peace, the claim by Vietnam’s leaders to be socialist looks like empty propaganda.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174"><a href="#cite_note-174">[167]</a></sup></p></blockquote>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Vietnam" title="Geography of Vietnam">Geography of Vietnam</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Geography_of_Vietnam.jpg"><img alt="Images showing Hạ Long Bay, the Yến River and the Bản-Giốc Waterfalls" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1152" data-file-width="1280" decoding="async" height="198" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Geography_of_Vietnam.jpg/220px-Geography_of_Vietnam.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Geography_of_Vietnam.jpg/330px-Geography_of_Vietnam.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Geography_of_Vietnam.jpg/440px-Geography_of_Vietnam.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Geography_of_Vietnam.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Nature attractions in Vietnam, clockwise from top: <a href="/wiki/H%E1%BA%A1_Long_Bay" title="Hạ Long Bay">Hạ Long Bay</a>, Yến River and <a href="/wiki/Ban_Gioc%E2%80%93Detian_Falls" title="Ban Gioc–Detian Falls">Bản-Giốc Waterfalls</a></div></div></div>
<p>Vietnam is located on the eastern <a href="/wiki/Mainland_Southeast_Asia" title="Mainland Southeast Asia">Indochinese Peninsula</a> between the latitudes <a href="/wiki/8th_parallel_north" title="8th parallel north">8°</a> and <a href="/wiki/24th_parallel_north" title="24th parallel north">24°N</a>, and the longitudes <a href="/wiki/102nd_meridian_east" title="102nd meridian east">102°</a> and <a href="/wiki/110th_meridian_east" title="110th meridian east">110°E</a>. It covers a total area of approximately 331,212 km<sup>2</sup> (127,882 sq mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-area_175-0"><a href="#cite_note-area-175">[n 8]</a></sup> The combined length of the country's land boundaries is 4,639 km (2,883 mi), and its coastline is 3,444 km (2,140 mi) long.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENasuchon20087_176-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENasuchon20087-176">[168]</a></sup> At its narrowest point in the central <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Qu%E1%BA%A3ng_B%C3%ACnh_Province" title="Quảng Bình Province">Quảng Bình Province</a>, the country is as little as 50 kilometres (31 mi) across, though it widens to around 600 kilometres (370 mi) in the north.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEProtected_Areas_and_Development_Partnership200313_177-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEProtected_Areas_and_Development_Partnership200313-177">[169]</a></sup> Vietnam's land is mostly hilly and densely forested, with level land covering no more than 20%. Mountains account for 40% of the country's land area,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFröhlichSchreinemachersStahrClemens20135_178-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFröhlichSchreinemachersStahrClemens20135-178">[170]</a></sup> and tropical forests cover around 42%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENatural_Resources_and_Environment_Program199556_179-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENatural_Resources_and_Environment_Program199556-179">[171]</a></sup> The Red River Delta in the north, a flat, roughly triangular region covering 15,000 km<sup>2</sup> (5,792 sq mi),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Ministry_of_Agriculture_and_Rural_Development2007_180-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Ministry_of_Agriculture_and_Rural_Development2007-180">[172]</a></sup> is smaller but more intensely developed and more densely populated than the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mekong_River_Delta" title="Mekong River Delta">Mekong River Delta</a> in the south. Once an inlet of the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Tonkin" title="Gulf of Tonkin">Gulf of Tonkin</a>, it has been filled in over the millennia by riverine <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Alluvial_deposits" title="Alluvial deposits">alluvial deposits</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHuu_Chiem1993180_181-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHuu_Chiem1993180-181">[173]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMinh_Hoangvan_LapKim_OanhJiro2016_182-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMinh_Hoangvan_LapKim_OanhJiro2016-182">[174]</a></sup> The delta, covering about 40,000 km<sup>2</sup> (15,444 sq mi), is a low-level plain no more than 3 metres (9.8 ft) <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Above_mean_sea_level" title="Above mean sea level">above sea level</a> at any point. It is criss-crossed by a maze of rivers and canals, which carry so much sediment that the delta advances 60 to 80 metres (196.9 to 262.5 ft) into the sea every year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHuu_Chiem1993183_183-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHuu_Chiem1993183-183">[175]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHong_TruongYeStive2017757_184-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHong_TruongYeStive2017757-184">[176]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Exclusive_economic_zone_of_Vietnam" title="Exclusive economic zone of Vietnam">exclusive economic zone of Vietnam</a> covers 417,663 km<sup>2</sup> (161,261 sq mi) in the <a href="/wiki/South_China_Sea" title="South China Sea">South China Sea</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnamese_Waters_Zone_185-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnamese_Waters_Zone-185">[177]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:I%27m_coming,_PXP.jpg"><img alt="Image of the Hoàng Liên Sơn mountain range" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="853" data-file-width="1280" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/I%27m_coming%2C_PXP.jpg/220px-I%27m_coming%2C_PXP.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/I%27m_coming%2C_PXP.jpg/330px-I%27m_coming%2C_PXP.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/I%27m_coming%2C_PXP.jpg/440px-I%27m_coming%2C_PXP.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:I%27m_coming,_PXP.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Hoàng Liên Sơn <a href="/wiki/Mountain_range" title="Mountain range">mountain range</a>, the range that includes <a href="/wiki/Fansipan" title="Fansipan">Fansipan</a> which is the highest summit on the Indochinese Peninsula.</div></div></div>
<p>Southern Vietnam is divided into coastal lowlands, the mountains of the <a href="/wiki/Annamite_Range" title="Annamite Range">Annamite Range</a>, and extensive forests. Comprising five relatively flat plateaus of <a href="/wiki/Basalt" title="Basalt">basalt</a> soil, the highlands account for 16% of the country's <a href="/wiki/Arable_land" title="Arable land">arable land</a> and 22% of its total forested land.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECosslettCosslett201713_186-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECosslettCosslett201713-186">[178]</a></sup> The soil in much of the southern part of Vietnam is relatively low in nutrients as a result of intense cultivation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVan_DeDouglasMcMorrowLindley2008_187-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVan_DeDouglasMcMorrowLindley2008-187">[179]</a></sup> Several minor <a href="/wiki/Earthquake" title="Earthquake">earthquakes</a> have been recorded in the past. Most have occurred near the northern Vietnamese border in the provinces of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C4%90i%E1%BB%87n_Bi%C3%AAn_Province" title="Điện Biên Province">Điện Biên</a>, Lào Cai and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/S%C6%A1n_La_Province" title="Sơn La Province">Sơn La</a>, while some have been recorded offshore of the central part of the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHong_Phuong20123_188-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHong_Phuong20123-188">[180]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE''Việt_Nam_News''2016_189-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE''Việt_Nam_News''2016-189">[181]</a></sup> The northern part of the country consists mostly of highlands and the Red River Delta. <a href="/wiki/Fansipan" title="Fansipan">Fansipan</a> (also known as Phan Xi Păng), which is located in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/L%C3%A0o_Cai_Province" title="Lào Cai Province">Lào Cai Province</a>, is the highest mountain in Vietnam, standing 3,143 m (10,312 ft) high.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Ministry_of_Culture,_Sports_and_Tourism2014_190-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Ministry_of_Culture,_Sports_and_Tourism2014-190">[182]</a></sup> From north to south Vietnam, the country also has <a href="/wiki/List_of_islands_of_Vietnam" title="List of islands of Vietnam">numerous islands</a>; <a href="/wiki/Ph%C3%BA_Qu%E1%BB%91c" title="Phú Quốc">Phú Quốc</a> is the largest.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBoobbyerSpooner2013173_191-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBoobbyerSpooner2013173-191">[183]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Hang_S%C6%A1n_%C4%90o%C3%B2ng" title="Hang Sơn Đoòng">Hang Sơn Đoòng</a> Cave is considered the largest known cave passage in the world since its discovery in 2009. The <a href="/wiki/Ba_B%E1%BB%83_Lake" title="Ba Bể Lake">Ba Bể Lake</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mekong" title="Mekong">Mekong</a> River are the largest lake and longest river in the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECosslettCosslett201313_192-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECosslettCosslett201313-192">[184]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAnh2016a_193-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAnh2016a-193">[185]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE''The_Telegraph''_194-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE''The_Telegraph''-194">[186]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_Vietnam" title="Climate of Vietnam">Climate of Vietnam</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Koppen-Geiger_Map_VNM_present.svg"><img alt="An image of the Köppen climate classification map of Vietnam" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="850" data-file-width="1145" decoding="async" height="163" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Koppen-Geiger_Map_VNM_present.svg/220px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_VNM_present.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Koppen-Geiger_Map_VNM_present.svg/330px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_VNM_present.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Koppen-Geiger_Map_VNM_present.svg/440px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_VNM_present.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Koppen-Geiger_Map_VNM_present.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Köppen climate classification">Köppen climate classification</a> map of Vietnam.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hanoi_Temple_of_Literature.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1944" data-file-width="2592" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Hanoi_Temple_of_Literature.jpg/220px-Hanoi_Temple_of_Literature.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Hanoi_Temple_of_Literature.jpg/330px-Hanoi_Temple_of_Literature.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Hanoi_Temple_of_Literature.jpg/440px-Hanoi_Temple_of_Literature.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hanoi_Temple_of_Literature.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Hanoi" title="Hanoi">Hanoi</a>, the Vietnam's capital having a <a href="/wiki/Humid_subtropical_climate" title="Humid subtropical climate">humid subtropical climate</a>.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:327px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Nha_Trang_skyline.jpg"><img alt="Photograph of Nha Trang beach with many high rise buildings behind it" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1213" data-file-width="2592" decoding="async" height="152" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Nha_Trang_skyline.jpg/325px-Nha_Trang_skyline.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Nha_Trang_skyline.jpg/488px-Nha_Trang_skyline.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Nha_Trang_skyline.jpg/650px-Nha_Trang_skyline.jpg 2x" width="325"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Nha_Trang_skyline.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Nha_Trang" title="Nha Trang">Nha Trang</a>, a popular beach destination having a <a href="/wiki/Tropical_savanna_climate" title="Tropical savanna climate">tropical savanna climate</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Due to differences in latitude and the marked variety in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Topographical_relief" title="Topographical relief">topographical relief</a>, Vietnam's climate tends to vary considerably for each region.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVu197966_195-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVu197966-195">[187]</a></sup> During the winter or dry season, extending roughly from November to April, the <a href="/wiki/Monsoon" title="Monsoon">monsoon</a> winds usually blow from the northeast along the Chinese coast and across the Gulf of Tonkin, picking up considerable moisture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERiehlAugstein19731_196-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERiehlAugstein19731-196">[188]</a></sup> The average annual temperature is generally higher in the plains than in the mountains, especially in southern Vietnam compared to the north. Temperatures vary less in the southern plains around Ho Chi Minh City and the Mekong Delta, ranging from between 21 and 35 °C (69.8 and 95.0 °F) over the year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuleen2017_197-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuleen2017-197">[189]</a></sup> In Hanoi and the surrounding areas of Red River Delta, the temperatures are much lower between 15 and 33 °C (59.0 and 91.4 °F).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuleen2017_197-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuleen2017-197">[189]</a></sup> Seasonal variations in the mountains, plateaus, and the northernmost areas are much more dramatic, with temperatures varying from 3 °C (37.4 °F) in December and January to 37 °C (98.6 °F) in July and August.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Net2018a_198-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Net2018a-198">[190]</a></sup> During winter, snow occasionally falls over the highest peaks of the far northern mountains near the Chinese border.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-199"><a href="#cite_note-199">[191]</a></sup> Vietnam receives high rates of <a href="/wiki/Precipitation" title="Precipitation">precipitation</a> in the form of rainfall with an average amount from 1,500 mm (59 in) to 2,000 mm (79 in) during the monsoon seasons; this often causes flooding, especially in the cities with poor drainage systems.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThi_Anh_200-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThi_Anh-200">[192]</a></sup> The country is also affected by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tropical_depression" title="Tropical depression">tropical depressions</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tropical_storm" title="Tropical storm">tropical storms</a> and <a href="/wiki/Typhoon" title="Typhoon">typhoons</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThi_Anh_200-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThi_Anh-200">[192]</a></sup> Vietnam is one of the most vulnerable countries to climate change, with 55% of its population living in low-elevation coastal areas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOverland2017_201-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOverland2017-201">[193]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202"><a href="#cite_note-202">[194]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">Biodiversity</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_Vietnam" title="Wildlife of Vietnam">Wildlife of Vietnam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Environmental_issues_in_Vietnam" title="Environmental issues in Vietnam">Environmental issues in Vietnam</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_endangered_species_in_Vietnam" title="List of endangered species in Vietnam">List of endangered species in Vietnam</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Protected_areas_of_Vietnam" title="Protected areas of Vietnam">Protected areas of Vietnam</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Wildlife_of_Vietnam.jpg"><img alt="Photographs of Native species in Vietnam the crested argus; the red-shanked douc, a monkey; the Indochinese leopard and the saola, a bovine." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="404" data-file-width="404" decoding="async" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Wildlife_of_Vietnam.jpg/220px-Wildlife_of_Vietnam.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Wildlife_of_Vietnam.jpg/330px-Wildlife_of_Vietnam.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/e9/Wildlife_of_Vietnam.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Wildlife_of_Vietnam.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Native species in Vietnam, clockwise from top-right: <a href="/wiki/Crested_argus" title="Crested argus">crested argus</a>, a peafowl, <a href="/wiki/Red-shanked_douc" title="Red-shanked douc">red-shanked douc</a>, <a href="/wiki/Indochinese_leopard" title="Indochinese leopard">Indochinese leopard</a>, <a href="/wiki/Saola" title="Saola">saola</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>As the country is located within the <a href="/wiki/Indomalayan_realm" title="Indomalayan realm">Indomalayan realm</a>, Vietnam is one of twenty-five countries considered to possess a uniquely high level of <a href="/wiki/Biodiversity" title="Biodiversity">biodiversity</a>. This was noted in the country's National Environmental Condition Report in 2005.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_National_Environment_Administration_203-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_National_Environment_Administration-203">[195]</a></sup> It is ranked 16th worldwide in biological diversity, being home to approximately 16% of the world's species. 15,986 species of <a href="/wiki/Flora" title="Flora">flora</a> have been identified in the country, of which 10% are <a href="/wiki/Endemism" title="Endemism">endemic</a>. Vietnam's <a href="/wiki/Fauna" title="Fauna">fauna</a> includes 307 <a href="/wiki/Nematode" title="Nematode">nematode</a> species, 200 <a href="/wiki/Oligochaeta" title="Oligochaeta">oligochaeta</a>, 145 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Acarina" title="Acarina">acarina</a>, 113 <a href="/wiki/Springtail" title="Springtail">springtails</a>, 7,750 insects, 260 reptiles, and 120 amphibians. There are 840 birds and 310 mammals are found in Vietnam, of which 100 birds and 78 mammals are endemic.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_National_Environment_Administration_203-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_National_Environment_Administration-203">[195]</a></sup> Vietnam has two <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World_Natural_Heritage_Site" title="World Natural Heritage Site">World Natural Heritage Sites</a>—the <a href="/wiki/H%E1%BA%A1_Long_Bay" title="Hạ Long Bay">Hạ Long Bay</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Phong_Nha-K%E1%BA%BB_B%C3%A0ng_National_Park" title="Phong Nha-Kẻ Bàng National Park">Phong Nha-Kẻ Bàng National Park</a>—together with nine <a href="/wiki/World_Network_of_Biosphere_Reserves_in_Asia_and_the_Pacific#Vietnam" title="World Network of Biosphere Reserves in Asia and the Pacific">biosphere reserves</a>, including <a href="/wiki/C%E1%BA%A7n_Gi%E1%BB%9D_Mangrove_Forest" title="Cần Giờ Mangrove Forest">Cần Giờ Mangrove Forest</a>, <a href="/wiki/C%C3%A1t_Ti%C3%AAn_National_Park" title="Cát Tiên National Park">Cát Tiên</a>, <a href="/wiki/C%C3%A1t_B%C3%A0_National_Park" title="Cát Bà National Park">Cát Bà</a>, <a href="/wiki/U_Minh_Th%C6%B0%E1%BB%A3ng_National_Park" title="U Minh Thượng National Park">Kiên Giang</a>, the Red River Delta, Mekong Delta, <a href="/wiki/Western_Ngh%E1%BB%87_An" title="Western Nghệ An">Western Nghệ An</a>, <a href="/wiki/M%C5%A9i_C%C3%A0_Mau_National_Park" title="Mũi Cà Mau National Park">Cà Mau</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Cu_Lao_Cham_Marine_Park" title="Cu Lao Cham Marine Park">Cu Lao Cham Marine Park</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUNESCO_World_Heritage_Convention1994_204-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUNESCO_World_Heritage_Convention1994-204">[196]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUNESCO_World_Heritage_Convention2003_205-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUNESCO_World_Heritage_Convention2003-205">[197]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPha_Le2016_206-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPha_Le2016-206">[198]</a></sup>
</p><p>Vietnam is also home to 1,438 species of freshwater <a href="/wiki/Microalgae" title="Microalgae">microalgae</a>, constituting 9.6% of all microalgae species, as well as 794 aquatic <a href="/wiki/Invertebrate" title="Invertebrate">invertebrates</a> and 2,458 species of sea fish.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_National_Environment_Administration_203-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_National_Environment_Administration-203">[195]</a></sup> In recent years, 13 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Genera" title="Genera">genera</a>, 222 species, and 30 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Taxa" title="Taxa">taxa</a> of flora have been newly described in Vietnam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_National_Environment_Administration_203-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_National_Environment_Administration-203">[195]</a></sup> Six new mammal species, including the <a href="/wiki/Saola" title="Saola">saola</a>, <a href="/wiki/Giant_muntjac" title="Giant muntjac">giant muntjac</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tonkin_snub-nosed_monkey" title="Tonkin snub-nosed monkey">Tonkin snub-nosed monkey</a> have also been discovered, along with one new bird species, the endangered <a href="/wiki/Edwards%27s_pheasant" title="Edwards's pheasant">Edwards's pheasant</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBirdLife_International2016_207-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBirdLife_International2016-207">[199]</a></sup> In the late 1980s, a small population of <a href="/wiki/Javan_rhinoceros" title="Javan rhinoceros">Javan rhinoceros</a> was found in Cát Tiên National Park. However, the last individual of the species in Vietnam was reportedly shot in 2010.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKinver2011_208-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKinver2011-208">[200]</a></sup> In agricultural <a href="/wiki/Genetic_diversity" title="Genetic diversity">genetic diversity</a>, Vietnam is one of the world's twelve original <a href="/wiki/Cultivar" title="Cultivar">cultivar</a> centres. The Vietnam National Cultivar Gene Bank preserves 12,300 cultivars of 115 species.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_National_Environment_Administration_203-4"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_National_Environment_Administration-203">[195]</a></sup> The Vietnamese government spent US$49.07 million on the preservation of biodiversity in 2004 alone and has established 126 conservation areas, including 30 <a href="/wiki/List_of_national_parks_of_Vietnam" title="List of national parks of Vietnam">national parks</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_National_Environment_Administration_203-5"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_National_Environment_Administration-203">[195]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sa_Pa_mountain_hills_with_agricultural_activities.jpg"><img alt="Photograph of the Sa Pa mountain hills with agricultural activity shiwn in the foreground" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1600" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="293" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Sa_Pa_mountain_hills_with_agricultural_activities.jpg/220px-Sa_Pa_mountain_hills_with_agricultural_activities.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Sa_Pa_mountain_hills_with_agricultural_activities.jpg/330px-Sa_Pa_mountain_hills_with_agricultural_activities.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Sa_Pa_mountain_hills_with_agricultural_activities.jpg/440px-Sa_Pa_mountain_hills_with_agricultural_activities.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Sa_Pa_mountain_hills_with_agricultural_activities.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sa_Pa_(town)" title="Sa Pa (town)">Sa Pa</a> mountain hills with <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_Vietnam" title="Agriculture in Vietnam">agricultural activities</a></div></div></div>
<p>In Vietnam, wildlife <a href="/wiki/Poaching" title="Poaching">poaching</a> has become a major concern. In 2000, a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Non-governmental_organisation" title="Non-governmental organisation">non-governmental organisation</a> (NGO) called <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Education_for_Nature_%E2%80%93_Vietnam&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Education for Nature – Vietnam (page does not exist)">Education for Nature – Vietnam</a> was founded to instill in the population the importance of wildlife conservation in the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDall2017_209-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDall2017-209">[201]</a></sup> In the years that followed, another NGO called GreenViet was formed by Vietnamese youngsters for the enforcement of wildlife protection. Through collaboration between the NGOs and local authorities, many local poaching syndicates were crippled by their leaders' arrests.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDall2017_209-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDall2017-209">[201]</a></sup> A study released in 2018 revealed Vietnam is a destination for the illegal export of <a href="/wiki/Rhinoceros" title="Rhinoceros">rhinoceros</a> horns from <a href="/wiki/South_Africa" title="South Africa">South Africa</a> due to the demand for them as a medicine and a status symbol.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDang_VuNielsen2018_210-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDang_VuNielsen2018-210">[202]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENam_DangNielsen2019_211-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENam_DangNielsen2019-211">[203]</a></sup>
</p><p>The main environmental concern that persists in Vietnam today is the legacy of the use of the chemical <a href="/wiki/Herbicide" title="Herbicide">herbicide</a> <a href="/wiki/Agent_Orange" title="Agent Orange">Agent Orange</a>, which continues to cause <a href="/wiki/Birth_defect" title="Birth defect">birth defects</a> and many health problems in the Vietnamese population. In the southern and central areas affected most by the chemical's use during the Vietnam War, nearly 4.8 million Vietnamese people have been exposed to it and suffered from its effects.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBanoutUrbanMusilSzakova2014_212-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBanoutUrbanMusilSzakova2014-212">[204]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECerre2016_213-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECerre2016-213">[205]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrown2018_214-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrown2018-214">[206]</a></sup> In 2012, approximately 50 years after the war,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAgence_France-Presse2016_215-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAgence_France-Presse2016-215">[207]</a></sup> the US began a <a href="/wiki/United_States_dollar" title="United States dollar">US</a>$43 million joint clean-up project in the former chemical storage areas in Vietnam to take place in stages.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECerre2016_213-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECerre2016-213">[205]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMacLeod2012_216-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMacLeod2012-216">[208]</a></sup> Following the completion of the first phase in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C4%90%C3%A0_N%E1%BA%B5ng" title="Đà Nẵng">Đà Nẵng</a> in late 2017,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnited_States_Agency_for_International_Development_217-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnited_States_Agency_for_International_Development-217">[209]</a></sup> the US announced its commitment to clean other sites, especially in the heavily impacted site of <a href="/wiki/Bi%C3%AAn_H%C3%B2a" title="Biên Hòa">Biên Hòa</a>, which is four times larger than the previously treated site, at an estimated cost of $390 million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStewart2018_218-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStewart2018-218">[210]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Vietnamese government spends over <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_%C4%91%E1%BB%93ng" title="Vietnamese đồng">VNĐ</a>10 trillion each year ($431.1 million) for monthly allowances and the physical rehabilitation of victims of the chemicals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE''Việt_Nam_News''2018a_219-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE''Việt_Nam_News''2018a-219">[211]</a></sup> In 2018, the Japanese engineering group <a href="/wiki/Shimizu_Corporation" title="Shimizu Corporation">Shimizu Corporation</a>, working with Vietnamese military, built a plant for the treatment of soil polluted by Agent Orange. Plant construction costs were funded by the company itself.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE''Nikkei_Asian_Review''2018_220-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE''Nikkei_Asian_Review''2018-220">[212]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENHK_World-Japan2018_221-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENHK_World-Japan2018-221">[213]</a></sup> One of the long-term plans to restore southern Vietnam's damaged <a href="/wiki/Ecosystem" title="Ecosystem">ecosystems</a> is through the use of <a href="/wiki/Reforestation" title="Reforestation">reforestation</a> efforts. The Vietnamese government began doing this at the end of the war. It started by replanting <a href="/wiki/Mangrove_forest" title="Mangrove forest">mangrove forests</a> in the Mekong Delta regions and in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/C%E1%BA%A7n_Gi%E1%BB%9D_District" title="Cần Giờ District">Cần Giờ</a> outside Hồ Chí Minh City, where mangroves are important to ease (though not eliminate) flood conditions during monsoon seasons.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAgent_Orange_Record_222-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAgent_Orange_Record-222">[214]</a></sup> The country had a 2019 <a href="/wiki/Forest_Landscape_Integrity_Index" title="Forest Landscape Integrity Index">Forest Landscape Integrity Index</a> mean score of 5.35/10, ranking it 104th globally out of 172 countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FLII-Supplementary_223-0"><a href="#cite_note-FLII-Supplementary-223">[215]</a></sup>
</p><p>Apart from herbicide problems, <a href="/wiki/Arsenic_poisoning" title="Arsenic poisoning">arsenic</a> in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ground_water" title="Ground water">ground water</a> in the Mekong and Red River Deltas has also become a major concern.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBergStengelPhamPham2007_224-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBergStengelPhamPham2007-224">[216]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMerolaHienQuyenVengosh2014_225-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMerolaHienQuyenVengosh2014-225">[217]</a></sup> And most notoriously, <a href="/wiki/Unexploded_ordnance" title="Unexploded ordnance">unexploded ordnances</a> (UXO) pose dangers to humans and wildlife—another bitter legacy from the long wars.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiguelRoland2005_226-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiguelRoland2005-226">[218]</a></sup> As part of the continuous campaign to <a href="/wiki/Demining" title="Demining">demine</a>/remove UXOs, several international <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mine_clearance_agency" title="Mine clearance agency">bomb removal agencies</a> from the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">United Kingdom</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnited_Kingdom_Department_for_International_Development2017_227-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnited_Kingdom_Department_for_International_Development2017-227">[219]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Denmark" title="Denmark">Denmark</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELM_Report2000_228-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELM_Report2000-228">[220]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/South_Korea" title="South Korea">South Korea</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnited_Nations_Development_Programme2018_229-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnited_Nations_Development_Programme2018-229">[221]</a></sup> and the US<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnited_States_Department_of_State2006_230-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnited_States_Department_of_State2006-230">[222]</a></sup> have been providing assistance. The Vietnam government spends over VNĐ1 trillion ($44 million) annually on demining operations and additional hundreds of billions of đồng for treatment, assistance, rehabilitation, vocational training and resettlement of the victims of UXOs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVan_Thanh2016_231-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVan_Thanh2016-231">[223]</a></sup> In 2017 the Chinese government also removed 53,000 land mines and explosives left over from the war between the two countries, in an area of 18.4 km<sup>2</sup> (7.1 sq mi) in the Chinese province of <a href="/wiki/Yunnan" title="Yunnan">Yunnan</a> bordering the <a href="/wiki/China%E2%80%93Vietnam_border" title="China–Vietnam border">China–Vietnam border</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETao2017_232-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETao2017-232">[224]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tnone" style="margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto;overflow:hidden;width:auto;max-width:1008px"><div class="thumbinner"><div class="noresize" style="overflow:auto"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Halong_Bay_panorama.jpg" title="Panoramic view of Hạ Long Bay"><img alt="" data-file-height="2062" data-file-width="5963" decoding="async" height="346" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Halong_Bay_panorama.jpg/1000px-Halong_Bay_panorama.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Halong_Bay_panorama.jpg/1500px-Halong_Bay_panorama.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Halong_Bay_panorama.jpg/2000px-Halong_Bay_panorama.jpg 2x" width="1000"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Halong_Bay_panorama.jpg" title="File:Halong Bay panorama.jpg"> </a></div>Panoramic view of <a href="/wiki/H%E1%BA%A1_Long_Bay" title="Hạ Long Bay">Hạ Long Bay</a></div></div></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Government_and_politics">Government and politics</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Vietnam" title="Politics of Vietnam">Politics of Vietnam</a> and <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Vietnam" title="Government of Vietnam">Government of Vietnam</a></div>
<p>Vietnam is a <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">unitary</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Marxism-Leninism" title="Marxism-Leninism">Marxist-Leninist</a> <a href="/wiki/One-party_state" title="One-party state">one-party</a> <a href="/wiki/Socialist_state" title="Socialist state">socialist</a> <a href="/wiki/Republic" title="Republic">republic</a>, one of the two <a href="/wiki/Communist_state" title="Communist state">communist states</a> (the other being <a href="/wiki/Laos" title="Laos">Laos</a>) in <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGovernment_of_Vietnam_(II)_233-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGovernment_of_Vietnam_(II)-233">[225]</a></sup> Although Vietnam remains officially committed to <a href="/wiki/Socialism" title="Socialism">socialism</a> as its defining creed, its economic policies have grown increasingly <a href="/wiki/Capitalism" title="Capitalism">capitalist</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGreenfield1994204_234-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGreenfield1994204-234">[226]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBacciniImpullittiMalesky2017_235-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBacciniImpullittiMalesky2017-235">[227]</a></sup> with <i><a href="/wiki/The_Economist" title="The Economist">The Economist</a></i> characterising its leadership as "ardently capitalist communists".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE''The_Economist''2008_236-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE''The_Economist''2008-236">[228]</a></sup> Under the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Vietnam" title="Constitution of Vietnam">constitution</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Vietnam" title="Communist Party of Vietnam">Communist Party of Vietnam</a> (CPV) asserts their role in all branches of the country's politics and society.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGovernment_of_Vietnam_(II)_233-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGovernment_of_Vietnam_(II)-233">[225]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/President_of_Vietnam" title="President of Vietnam">president</a> is the elected <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">head of state</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Commander-in-chief" title="Commander-in-chief">commander-in-chief</a> of the military, serving as the chairman of the Council of Supreme Defence and Security, and holds the second highest office in Vietnam as well as performing executive functions and state appointments and setting policy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGovernment_of_Vietnam_(II)_233-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGovernment_of_Vietnam_(II)-233">[225]</a></sup>
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .multiimageinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle .thumbcaption{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow>.thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/General_Secretary_of_the_Communist_Party_of_Vietnam" title="General Secretary of the Communist Party of Vietnam">general secretary</a> of the CPV performs numerous key administrative functions, controlling the party's national organisation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGovernment_of_Vietnam_(II)_233-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGovernment_of_Vietnam_(II)-233">[225]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Vietnam" title="Prime Minister of Vietnam">prime minister</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">head of government</a>, presiding over a council of ministers composed of five deputy prime ministers and the heads of 26 ministries and commissions. Only political organisations affiliated with or endorsed by the CPV are permitted to contest elections in Vietnam. These include the <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_Fatherland_Front" title="Vietnamese Fatherland Front">Vietnamese Fatherland Front</a> and worker and <a href="/wiki/Trade_union" title="Trade union">trade unionist</a> parties.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGovernment_of_Vietnam_(II)_233-4"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGovernment_of_Vietnam_(II)-233">[225]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:National_Assembly_of_Vietnam.JPG"><img alt="Photograph of the National Assembly of Vietnam in Hanoi" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="5184" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/National_Assembly_of_Vietnam.JPG/220px-National_Assembly_of_Vietnam.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/National_Assembly_of_Vietnam.JPG/330px-National_Assembly_of_Vietnam.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/National_Assembly_of_Vietnam.JPG/440px-National_Assembly_of_Vietnam.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:National_Assembly_of_Vietnam.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_Assembly_of_Vietnam" title="National Assembly of Vietnam">National Assembly of Vietnam</a> building in Hanoi</div></div></div>
<p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_Assembly_of_Vietnam" title="National Assembly of Vietnam">National Assembly of Vietnam</a> is the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Unicameral" title="Unicameral">unicameral</a> state <a href="/wiki/Legislature" title="Legislature">legislature</a> composed of 500 members.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEmbassy_of_Vietnam_in_USA_237-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEmbassy_of_Vietnam_in_USA-237">[229]</a></sup> Headed by a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Chairmen_of_the_Standing_Committee_of_the_National_Assembly_of_Vietnam" title="List of Chairmen of the Standing Committee of the National Assembly of Vietnam">chairman</a>, it is superior to both the executive and judicial branches, with all government ministers being appointed from members of the National Assembly.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGovernment_of_Vietnam_(II)_233-5"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGovernment_of_Vietnam_(II)-233">[225]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Supreme_People%27s_Court_of_Vietnam" title="Supreme People's Court of Vietnam">Supreme People's Court of Vietnam</a>, headed by a chief justice, is the country's highest <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Court_of_appeal" title="Court of appeal">court of appeal</a>, though it is also answerable to the National Assembly. Beneath the Supreme People's Court stand the <a href="/wiki/Provincial_Municipal_Courts_of_Vietnam" title="Provincial Municipal Courts of Vietnam">provincial municipal courts</a> and many <a href="/wiki/Local_Courts_of_Vietnam" title="Local Courts of Vietnam">local courts</a>. <a href="/wiki/Military_Courts_of_Vietnam" title="Military Courts of Vietnam">Military courts</a> possess special jurisdiction in matters of <a href="/wiki/National_security" title="National security">state security</a>. Vietnam maintains the <a href="/wiki/Capital_punishment_in_Vietnam" title="Capital punishment in Vietnam">death penalty</a> for numerous offences.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Penal_Code1999_238-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Penal_Code1999-238">[230]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Vietnam" title="Foreign relations of Vietnam">Foreign relations of Vietnam</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tr%E1%BA%A7n_%C4%90%E1%BA%A1i_Quang_and_Vladimir_Putin,_2016-01.jpg"><img alt="Trần Đại Quang and Vladimir Putin" data-file-height="1160" data-file-width="1880" decoding="async" height="123" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Tr%E1%BA%A7n_%C4%90%E1%BA%A1i_Quang_and_Vladimir_Putin%2C_2016-01.jpg/200px-Tr%E1%BA%A7n_%C4%90%E1%BA%A1i_Quang_and_Vladimir_Putin%2C_2016-01.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Tr%E1%BA%A7n_%C4%90%E1%BA%A1i_Quang_and_Vladimir_Putin%2C_2016-01.jpg/300px-Tr%E1%BA%A7n_%C4%90%E1%BA%A1i_Quang_and_Vladimir_Putin%2C_2016-01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Tr%E1%BA%A7n_%C4%90%E1%BA%A1i_Quang_and_Vladimir_Putin%2C_2016-01.jpg/400px-Tr%E1%BA%A7n_%C4%90%E1%BA%A1i_Quang_and_Vladimir_Putin%2C_2016-01.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">President <a href="/wiki/Tr%E1%BA%A7n_%C4%90%E1%BA%A1i_Quang" title="Trần Đại Quang">Trần Đại Quang</a> with Russian President <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Putin" title="Vladimir Putin">Vladimir Putin</a> on 19 November 2016.</div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Secretary_Tillerson_Joins_Commercial_Deals_Signing_Ceremony_at_the_Presidential_Palace_in_Vietnam_(38322247422).jpg"><img alt="Secretary Tillerson at the Presidential Palace" data-file-height="2759" data-file-width="4431" decoding="async" height="125" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Secretary_Tillerson_Joins_Commercial_Deals_Signing_Ceremony_at_the_Presidential_Palace_in_Vietnam_%2838322247422%29.jpg/200px-Secretary_Tillerson_Joins_Commercial_Deals_Signing_Ceremony_at_the_Presidential_Palace_in_Vietnam_%2838322247422%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Secretary_Tillerson_Joins_Commercial_Deals_Signing_Ceremony_at_the_Presidential_Palace_in_Vietnam_%2838322247422%29.jpg/300px-Secretary_Tillerson_Joins_Commercial_Deals_Signing_Ceremony_at_the_Presidential_Palace_in_Vietnam_%2838322247422%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Secretary_Tillerson_Joins_Commercial_Deals_Signing_Ceremony_at_the_Presidential_Palace_in_Vietnam_%2838322247422%29.jpg/400px-Secretary_Tillerson_Joins_Commercial_Deals_Signing_Ceremony_at_the_Presidential_Palace_in_Vietnam_%2838322247422%29.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">US Secretary of State <a href="/wiki/Rex_Tillerson" title="Rex Tillerson">Rex Tillerson</a> accompanies US President <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump" title="Donald Trump">Donald Trump</a> to a commercial deal signing ceremony with Vietnamese President on 12 November 2017.</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Throughout its history, Vietnam's main foreign relationship has been with various Chinese dynasties.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThayer1994_239-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThayer1994-239">[231]</a></sup> Following the partition of Vietnam in 1954, North Vietnam maintained relations with the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Bloc" title="Eastern Bloc">Eastern Bloc</a>, South Vietnam maintained relations with the <a href="/wiki/Western_Bloc" title="Western Bloc">Western Bloc</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThayer1994_239-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThayer1994-239">[231]</a></sup> Despite these differences, Vietnam's sovereign principles and insistence on cultural independence have been laid down in numerous documents over the centuries before its independence. These include the 11th-century patriotic poem "<i><a href="/wiki/Nam_qu%E1%BB%91c_s%C6%A1n_h%C3%A0" title="Nam quốc sơn hà">Nam quốc sơn hà</a></i>" and the 1428 proclamation of independence "<i><a href="/wiki/B%C3%ACnh_Ng%C3%B4_%C4%91%E1%BA%A1i_c%C3%A1o" title="Bình Ngô đại cáo">Bình Ngô đại cáo</a></i>". Though China and Vietnam are now formally at peace,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThayer1994_239-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThayer1994-239">[231]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Spratly_Islands#Military_conflict_and_diplomatic_dialogues" title="Spratly Islands">significant territorial tensions</a> remain between the two countries over the South China Sea.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThanh_Hai2016177_240-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThanh_Hai2016177-240">[232]</a></sup> Vietnam holds membership in 63 international organisations, including the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a> (UN), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Association_of_Southeast_Asian_Nations" title="Association of Southeast Asian Nations">Association of Southeast Asian Nations</a> (ASEAN), <a href="/wiki/Non-Aligned_Movement" title="Non-Aligned Movement">Non-Aligned Movement</a> (NAM), <a href="/wiki/Organisation_internationale_de_la_Francophonie" title="Organisation internationale de la Francophonie">International Organisation of the Francophonie</a> (La Francophonie), and <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a> (WTO). It also maintains relations with over 650 non-governmental organisations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs2018_241-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs2018-241">[233]</a></sup> As of 2010 Vietnam had established diplomatic relations with 178 countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs2013_242-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs2013-242">[234]</a></sup>
</p><p>Vietnam's current foreign policy is to consistently implement a policy of independence, self-reliance, peace, co-operation, and development, as well openness, diversification, <a href="/wiki/Multilateralism" title="Multilateralism">multilateralisation</a> with international relations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs2007_243-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs2007-243">[235]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs2014_244-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs2014-244">[236]</a></sup> The country declares itself a friend and partner of all countries in the international community, regardless of their political affiliation, by actively taking part in international and regional cooperative development projects.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBich_Loan2007_169-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBich_Loan2007-169">[162]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs2007_243-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs2007-243">[235]</a></sup> Since the 1990s, Vietnam has taken several key steps to restore diplomatic ties with capitalist <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Western_countries" title="Western countries">Western countries</a>. It already had relations with communist Western countries in the decades prior.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDayley201898_245-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDayley201898-245">[237]</a></sup> Relations with the United States <a href="/wiki/United_States%E2%80%93Vietnam_relations" title="United States–Vietnam relations">began improving</a> in August 1995 with both states upgrading their <i><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/liaison" title="wikt:liaison">liaison</a></i> offices to embassy status.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMitchell1995_246-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMitchell1995-246">[238]</a></sup> As diplomatic ties between the two governments grew, the United States opened a <a href="/wiki/Consul_(representative)" title="Consul (representative)">consulate general</a> in Ho Chi Minh City while Vietnam opened <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_diplomatic_missions_in_San_Francisco" title="List of diplomatic missions in San Francisco">its consulate</a> in <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco" title="San Francisco">San Francisco</a>. Full diplomatic relations were also restored with <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand" title="New Zealand">New Zealand</a>, which opened its embassy in Hanoi in 1995;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGreen2012_247-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGreen2012-247">[239]</a></sup> Vietnam established an embassy in <a href="/wiki/Wellington" title="Wellington">Wellington</a> in 2003.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESmith2005386_248-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESmith2005386-248">[240]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a> also reopened its embassy in Hanoi in October 2000, with Vietnam reopening its embassy in <a href="/wiki/Islamabad" title="Islamabad">Islamabad</a> in December 2005 and trade office in <a href="/wiki/Karachi" title="Karachi">Karachi</a> in November 2005.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEInstitute_of_Regional_Studies200166_249-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEInstitute_of_Regional_Studies200166-249">[241]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_250-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs-250">[242]</a></sup> In May 2016, US President <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">Barack Obama</a> further normalised relations with Vietnam after he announced the lifting of an arms <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_States_embargoes" title="United States embargoes">embargo</a> on sales of lethal arms to Vietnam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGaramone2016_251-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGaramone2016-251">[243]</a></sup> Despite their historical past, today Vietnam is considered to be a potential ally of the United States, especially in the geopolitical context of the <a href="/wiki/Territorial_disputes_in_the_South_China_Sea" title="Territorial disputes in the South China Sea">territorial disputes in the South China Sea</a> and in containment of <a href="/wiki/Chinese_expansionism" title="Chinese expansionism">Chinese expansionism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHutt2020_252-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHutt2020-252">[244]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECorr2019_253-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECorr2019-253">[245]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETran2020_254-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETran2020-254">[246]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_People%27s_Armed_Forces" title="Vietnam People's Armed Forces">Vietnam People's Armed Forces</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vietnam_People%27s_Armed_Forces.jpg"><img alt="Photographs of Vietnam People's Armed Forces weaponry assets including a T-54B tank, a Sukhoi Su-27UBK fighter aircraft, a Vietnam Coast Guard Hamilton-class cutter, and a Vietnam People's Army chemical corps carrying a Type 56 assault rifle." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="312" data-file-width="560" decoding="async" height="123" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Vietnam_People%27s_Armed_Forces.jpg/220px-Vietnam_People%27s_Armed_Forces.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Vietnam_People%27s_Armed_Forces.jpg/330px-Vietnam_People%27s_Armed_Forces.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Vietnam_People%27s_Armed_Forces.jpg/440px-Vietnam_People%27s_Armed_Forces.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Vietnam_People%27s_Armed_Forces.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Examples of the <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_People%27s_Armed_Forces" title="Vietnam People's Armed Forces">Vietnam People's Armed Forces</a> weaponry assets. Clockwise from top right: <a href="/wiki/T-54/T-55" title="T-54/T-55">T-54B tank</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sukhoi_Su-27" title="Sukhoi Su-27">Sukhoi Su-27</a>UBK fighter aircraft, <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_Coast_Guard" title="Vietnam Coast Guard">Vietnam Coast Guard</a> <a href="/wiki/Hamilton-class_cutter" title="Hamilton-class cutter">Hamilton-class cutter</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vietnam_People%27s_Army" title="Vietnam People's Army">Vietnam People's Army</a> chemical corps with <a href="/wiki/Type_56_assault_rifle" title="Type 56 assault rifle">Type 56</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_People%27s_Armed_Forces" title="Vietnam People's Armed Forces">Vietnam People's Armed Forces</a> consists of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vietnam_People%27s_Army" title="Vietnam People's Army">Vietnam People's Army</a> (VPA), the <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_People%27s_Public_Security" title="Vietnam People's Public Security">Vietnam People's Public Security</a> and the Vietnam Self-Defence Militia. The VPA is the official name for the active military services of Vietnam, and is subdivided into the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vietnam_People%27s_Ground_Forces" title="Vietnam People's Ground Forces">Vietnam People's Ground Forces</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_People%27s_Navy" title="Vietnam People's Navy">Vietnam People's Navy</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_People%27s_Air_Force" title="Vietnam People's Air Force">Vietnam People's Air Force</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_Border_Guard" title="Vietnam Border Guard">Vietnam Border Guard</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_Coast_Guard" title="Vietnam Coast Guard">Vietnam Coast Guard</a>. The VPA has an active manpower of around 450,000, but its total strength, including paramilitary forces, may be as high as 5,000,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaylorRutherford201150_255-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaylorRutherford201150-255">[247]</a></sup> In 2015, Vietnam's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_military_expenditures" title="List of countries by military expenditures">military expenditure</a> totalled approximately US$4.4 billion, equivalent to around 8% of its total government spending.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEYan2016_256-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEYan2016-256">[248]</a></sup> Joint military exercises and war games have been held with <a href="/wiki/Brunei" title="Brunei">Brunei</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVoice_of_Vietnam2016_257-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVoice_of_Vietnam2016-257">[249]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE''The_Economic_Times''2018_258-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE''The_Economic_Times''2018-258">[250]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">Japan</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE''The_Japan_Times''2015_259-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE''The_Japan_Times''2015-259">[251]</a></sup> Laos,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVoice_of_Vietnam2018b_260-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVoice_of_Vietnam2018b-260">[252]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERussia_Ministry_of_Defence2018_261-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERussia_Ministry_of_Defence2018-261">[253]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Singapore" title="Singapore">Singapore</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVoice_of_Vietnam2016_257-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVoice_of_Vietnam2016-257">[249]</a></sup> and the US.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE''The_Telegraph''2012_262-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE''The_Telegraph''2012-262">[254]</a></sup> In 2017, Vietnam signed the UN treaty on the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_on_the_Prohibition_of_Nuclear_Weapons" title="Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons">Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnited_Nations_Treaty_Collection_263-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnited_Nations_Treaty_Collection-263">[255]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGiap2017_264-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGiap2017-264">[256]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Human_rights_and_sociopolitical_issues">Human rights and sociopolitical issues</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Vietnam" title="Human rights in Vietnam">Human rights in Vietnam</a></div>
<p>Under the current constitution, the CPV is the only party allowed to rule, the operation of all other political parties being outlawed. Other human rights issues concern <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_association" title="Freedom of association">freedom of association</a>, <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_speech" title="Freedom of speech">freedom of speech</a>, <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_religion" title="Freedom of religion">freedom of religion</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_the_press" title="Freedom of the press">freedom of the press</a>. In 2009, Vietnamese lawyer <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/L%C3%AA_C%C3%B4ng_%C4%90%E1%BB%8Bnh" title="Lê Công Định">Lê Công Định</a> was arrested and charged with the capital crime of <a href="/wiki/Subversion" title="Subversion">subversion</a>; several of his associates were also arrested.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBBC_News2009_265-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBBC_News2009-265">[257]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMydans2009_266-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMydans2009-266">[258]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Amnesty_International" title="Amnesty International">Amnesty International</a> described him and his arrested associates as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prisoners_of_conscience" title="Prisoners of conscience">prisoners of conscience</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBBC_News2009_265-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBBC_News2009-265">[257]</a></sup> Vietnam has also suffered from human trafficking and related issues.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267"><a href="#cite_note-267">[259]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268"><a href="#cite_note-268">[260]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto3_269-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto3-269">[261]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Subdivisions_of_Vietnam" title="Subdivisions of Vietnam">Subdivisions of Vietnam</a></div>
<p>Vietnam is divided into 58 <a href="/wiki/Province" title="Province">provinces</a> (Vietnamese: <i lang="vi">Tỉnh</i>, <a href="/wiki/Ch%E1%BB%AF_H%C3%A1n" title="Chữ Hán">chữ Hán</a>: <span lang="vi"><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E7%9C%81#Vietnamese" title="wikt:省">省</a></span>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJapan_Ministry_of_Land,_Infrastructure,_Transport_and_Tourism_270-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJapan_Ministry_of_Land,_Infrastructure,_Transport_and_Tourism-270">[262]</a></sup> There are also five <a href="/wiki/Municipality" title="Municipality">municipalities</a> (<span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi">thành phố trực thuộc trung ương</i></span>), which are administratively on the same level as provinces.
</p>
<div>
<table class="multicol" role="presentation" style="border-collapse: collapse; padding: 0; border: 0; background:transparent; width:auto;">
<tbody><tr>
<td style="text-align: left; vertical-align: top;">
<table align="none" cellpadding="10" style="width:0; border-spacing:0px; text-align:center; background-color:#f9f9f9; border:1px solid #cccccc">
<tbody><tr>
<td style="border:solid 1px #cccccc">
<div class="noresize" role="img" style="width: 400px; line-height: 1; text-align: center; background-color: #ffffff; position: relative;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vietnam_location_map.svg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2349" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="783" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Vietnam_location_map.svg/400px-Vietnam_location_map.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Vietnam_location_map.svg/600px-Vietnam_location_map.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Vietnam_location_map.svg/800px-Vietnam_location_map.svg.png 2x" width="400"/></a>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:179px; top:142px"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/H%C3%A0_N%E1%BB%99i" title="Hà Nội">1</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:224px; top:642px"><a href="/wiki/Ho_Chi_Minh_City" title="Ho Chi Minh City">2</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:224px; top:152px"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/H%E1%BA%A3i_Ph%C3%B2ng" title="Hải Phòng">3</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:292px; top:383px"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C4%90%C3%A0_N%E1%BA%B5ng" title="Đà Nẵng">4</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:171px; top:674px"><a href="/wiki/C%E1%BA%A7n_Th%C6%A1" title="Cần Thơ">5</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:62px; top:107px"><a href="/wiki/%C4%90i%E1%BB%87n_Bi%C3%AAn_province" title="Điện Biên province">6</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:69px; top:77px"><a href="/wiki/Lai_Ch%C3%A2u_province" title="Lai Châu province">7</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:104px; top:77px"><a href="/wiki/L%C3%A0o_Cai_province" title="Lào Cai province">8</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:144px; top:62px"><a href="/wiki/H%C3%A0_Giang_province" title="Hà Giang province">9</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:194px; top:57px"><a href="/wiki/Cao_B%E1%BA%B1ng_province" title="Cao Bằng province">10</a></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:214px; top:102px"><a href="/wiki/L%E1%BA%A1ng_S%C6%A1n_province" title="Lạng Sơn province">11</a></div>

<p><big><b>Provinces of Vietnam</b></big>
</p><p><small><i>Island areas:</i></small>
</p><p>*-<small><a href="/wiki/Ph%C3%BA_Qu%E1%BB%91c" title="Phú Quốc">Phú Quốc Island</a> (Phú Quốc City, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ki%C3%AAn_Giang_Province" title="Kiên Giang Province">Kiên Giang Province</a> [58])</small>
</p><p>**-<small><a href="/wiki/C%C3%B4n_%C4%90%E1%BA%A3o" title="Côn Đảo">Côn Đảo Islands</a> (<a href="/wiki/C%C3%B4n_%C4%90%E1%BA%A3o" title="Côn Đảo">Côn Đảo District</a>, <a href="/wiki/B%C3%A0_R%E1%BB%8Ba%E2%80%93V%C5%A9ng_T%C3%A0u_province" title="Bà Rịa–Vũng Tàu province">Bà Rịa–Vũng Tàu province</a> [51])</small>
</p><p>***-<small><a href="/wiki/Paracel_Islands" title="Paracel Islands">Paracel Islands</a> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ho%C3%A0ng_Sa_District" title="Hoàng Sa District">Hoàng Sa District</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C4%90%C3%A0_N%E1%BA%B5ng" title="Đà Nẵng">Đà Nẵng Municipality</a> [4])</small>
</p><p>****-<small><a href="/wiki/Spratly_Islands" title="Spratly Islands">Spratly Islands</a> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tr%C6%B0%E1%BB%9Dng_Sa_District" title="Trường Sa District">Trường Sa District</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kh%C3%A1nh_H%C3%B2a_Province" title="Khánh Hòa Province">Khánh Hòa Province</a> [43])</small>
</p>
