The government will continue investing in education especially for the poor to have access to basic education.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE''Vietnam_Net''2016b_388-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE''Vietnam_Net''2016b-388">[380]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Vietnam" title="Demographics of Vietnam">Demographics of Vietnam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_people" title="Vietnamese people">Vietnamese people</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethnic_groups_in_Vietnam" title="Ethnic groups in Vietnam">Ethnic groups in Vietnam</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:352px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vietnam_population_pyramid_01.04.2019.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1840" data-file-width="2212" decoding="async" height="291" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Vietnam_population_pyramid_01.04.2019.png/350px-Vietnam_population_pyramid_01.04.2019.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Vietnam_population_pyramid_01.04.2019.png/525px-Vietnam_population_pyramid_01.04.2019.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Vietnam_population_pyramid_01.04.2019.png/700px-Vietnam_population_pyramid_01.04.2019.png 2x" width="350"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Vietnam_population_pyramid_01.04.2019.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Vietnam population pyramid in 2019</div></div></div>
<p>As of 2021<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Vietnam&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, the population of Vietnam stands at approximately 97.5 million people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnited_Nations_Department_of_Economic_and_Social_Affairs_389-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnited_Nations_Department_of_Economic_and_Social_Affairs-389">[381]</a></sup> The population had grown significantly from the 1979 census, which showed the total population of reunified Vietnam to be 52.7 million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFraser1980_390-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFraser1980-390">[382]</a></sup> According to the 2019 census, the country's population was 96,208,984.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGeneral_Statistics_Office_of_Vietnam2019_3-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGeneral_Statistics_Office_of_Vietnam2019-3">[2]</a></sup> Based on the 2019 census, 65.6% of the Vietnamese population live in rural areas while only 34.4% live in urban areas. The average growth rate of the urban population has recently increased which is attributed mainly to migration and rapid urbanisation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGeneral_Statistics_Office_of_Vietnam2019_3-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGeneral_Statistics_Office_of_Vietnam2019-3">[2]</a></sup> The dominant <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Viet_people" title="Viet people">Viet</a> or Kinh ethnic group constitute 82,085,826 people or 85.32% of the population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGeneral_Statistics_Office_of_Vietnam2019_3-4"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGeneral_Statistics_Office_of_Vietnam2019-3">[2]</a></sup> Most of their population is concentrated in the country's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Alluvial_fans" title="Alluvial fans">alluvial deltas</a> and coastal plains. As a majority ethnic group, the Kinh possess significant political and economic influence over the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJones199821_391-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJones199821-391">[383]</a></sup> Despite this, Vietnam is also home to various ethnic groups, of which <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethnic_groups_in_Vietnam" title="Ethnic groups in Vietnam">54 are officially recognised</a>, including the <a href="/wiki/Hmong_people" title="Hmong people">Hmong</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yao_people" title="Yao people">Dao</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tay_people" title="Tay people">Tày</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Thai_people_in_Vietnam" title="Thai people in Vietnam">Thái</a> and <a href="/wiki/N%C3%B9ng_people" title="Nùng people">Nùng</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECanada_Ministry_of_Citizenship_and_Immigration20131_392-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECanada_Ministry_of_Citizenship_and_Immigration20131-392">[384]</a></sup> Many ethnic minorities such as the <a href="/wiki/Muong_people" title="Muong people">Muong</a>, who are closely related to the Kinh, dwell in the highlands which cover two-thirds of Vietnam's territory.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGovernment_of_Vietnam_(I)_393-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGovernment_of_Vietnam_(I)-393">[385]</a></sup>
</p><p>Other uplanders in the north migrated from southern China between the 1300s and 1800s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoskoff20081316_394-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoskoff20081316-394">[386]</a></sup> Since the partition of Vietnam, the population of the <a href="/wiki/Central_Highlands_(Vietnam)" title="Central Highlands (Vietnam)">Central Highlands</a> was almost exclusively <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Degar" title="Degar">Degar</a> (including more than 40 tribal groups); however, the South Vietnamese government at the time enacted a program of resettling Kinh in indigenous areas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECultural_Orientation_Resource_Centre7_395-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECultural_Orientation_Resource_Centre7-395">[387]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMontagnard_Human_Rights_Organisation_396-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontagnard_Human_Rights_Organisation-396">[388]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Hoa_people" title="Hoa people">Hoa</a> (ethnic <a href="/wiki/Overseas_Chinese" title="Overseas Chinese">Chinese</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Khmer_Krom" title="Khmer Krom">Khmer Krom</a> people are mainly lowlanders.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJones199821_391-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJones199821-391">[383]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoskoff20081316_394-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoskoff20081316-394">[386]</a></sup> Throughout Vietnam's history, many Chinese people, largely from <a href="/wiki/South_China" title="South China">South China</a>, migrated to the country as administrators, merchants and even refugees.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDoddLewis2003531_397-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDoddLewis2003531-397">[389]</a></sup> Since the reunification in 1976, an increase of communist policies nationwide resulted in the nationalisation and confiscation of property especially from the Hoa in the south and the wealthy in cities. This led many of them to leave Vietnam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAmer1996_398-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAmer1996-398">[390]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFeinberg2016_399-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFeinberg2016-399">[391]</a></sup> Furthermore, with the deterioration of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sino-Vietnamese_relations" title="Sino-Vietnamese relations">Sino-Vietnamese relations</a> after the <a href="/wiki/Sino-Vietnamese_War" title="Sino-Vietnamese War">border invasion</a> by Chinese government in 1979 many Vietnamese were wary of Chinese government's intentions. This indirectly caused more Hoa people in the north to leave the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDoddLewis2003531_397-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDoddLewis2003531-397">[389]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGough1986_400-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGough1986-400">[392]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Urbanisation">Urbanisation</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Vietnam" title="List of cities in Vietnam">List of cities in Vietnam</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ho_Chi_Minh_City_Skyline_(night).jpg"><img alt="Ho Chi Minh City's District 1 skyline photographed at night" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1815" data-file-width="3304" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Ho_Chi_Minh_City_Skyline_%28night%29.jpg/300px-Ho_Chi_Minh_City_Skyline_%28night%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Ho_Chi_Minh_City_Skyline_%28night%29.jpg/450px-Ho_Chi_Minh_City_Skyline_%28night%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Ho_Chi_Minh_City_Skyline_%28night%29.jpg/600px-Ho_Chi_Minh_City_Skyline_%28night%29.jpg 2x" width="300"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ho_Chi_Minh_City_Skyline_(night).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/District_1,_Ho_Chi_Minh_City" title="District 1, Ho Chi Minh City">District 1</a>, Ho Chi Minh City.</div></div></div>
<p>The number of people who live in urbanised areas in 2019 is 33,122,548 people (with the urbanisation rate at 34.4%).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGeneral_Statistics_Office_of_Vietnam2019_3-5"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGeneral_Statistics_Office_of_Vietnam2019-3">[2]</a></sup> Since 1986, Vietnam's urbanisation rates have surged rapidly after the Vietnamese government implemented the Đổi Mới economic program, changing the system into a socialist one and liberalising property rights. As a result, Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City (the two major cities in the Red River Delta and Southeast regions respectively) increased their share of the total urban population from 8.5% and 24.9% to 15.9% and 31% respectively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_General_Statistics_Office2009b117_401-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_General_Statistics_Office2009b117-401">[393]</a></sup> The Vietnamese government, through its <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Construction_(Vietnam)" title="Ministry of Construction (Vietnam)">construction ministry</a>, forecasts the country will have a 45% urbanisation rate by 2020 although it was confirmed to only be 34.4% according to the 2019 census.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGeneral_Statistics_Office_of_Vietnam2019_3-6"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGeneral_Statistics_Office_of_Vietnam2019-3">[2]</a></sup> Urbanisation is said to have a positive correlation with economic growth. Any country with higher urbanisation rates has a higher GDP growth rate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWorld_Bank2002_402-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWorld_Bank2002-402">[394]</a></sup> Furthermore, the urbanisation movement in Vietnam is mainly between the rural areas and the country's Southeast region. Ho Chi Minh City has received a large number of migrants due mainly to better weather and economic opportunities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_General_Statistics_Office2009b102_403-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_General_Statistics_Office2009b102-403">[395]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:West_Hanoi.jpg"><img alt="Photograph showing the large number of high-rise buildings in west Hanoi" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="435" data-file-width="1024" decoding="async" height="93" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/West_Hanoi.jpg/220px-West_Hanoi.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/West_Hanoi.jpg/330px-West_Hanoi.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/West_Hanoi.jpg/440px-West_Hanoi.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:West_Hanoi.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Urbanisation in west Hanoi</div></div></div>
<p>A study also shows that rural-to-urban area migrants have a higher standard of living than both non-migrants in rural areas and non-migrants in urban areas. This results in changes to economic structures. In 1985, agriculture made up 37.2% of Vietnam's GDP; in 2008, that number had declined to 18.5%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECiraDasturKilroyLozano2011194_404-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECiraDasturKilroyLozano2011194-404">[396]</a></sup> In 1985, industry made up only 26.2% of Vietnam's GDP; by 2008, that number had increased to 43.2%. Urbanisation also helps to improve basic services which increase people's standards of living. Access to electricity grew from 14% of total households with electricity in 1993 to above 96% in 2009.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECiraDasturKilroyLozano2011194_404-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECiraDasturKilroyLozano2011194-404">[396]</a></sup> In terms of access to fresh water, data from 65 utility companies shows that only 12% of households in the area covered by them had access to the water network in 2002; by 2007, more than 70% of the population was connected. Though urbanisation has many benefits, it has some drawbacks since it creates more traffic, and air and water pollution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECiraDasturKilroyLozano2011194_404-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECiraDasturKilroyLozano2011194-404">[396]</a></sup>
</p><p>Many Vietnamese use <a href="/wiki/Moped" title="Moped">mopeds</a> for transportation, since they are relatively cheap and easy to operate. Their large numbers have been known to cause traffic congestion and air pollution in Vietnam. In the capital city alone, the number of mopeds increased from 0.5 million in 2001 to 4.7 million in 2013.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECiraDasturKilroyLozano2011194_404-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECiraDasturKilroyLozano2011194-404">[396]</a></sup> With rapid development, factories have sprung up which indirectly pollute the air and water. An example is the <a href="/wiki/2016_Vietnam_marine_life_disaster" title="2016 Vietnam marine life disaster">2016 Vietnam marine life disaster</a> caused by the <a href="/wiki/Formosa_Ha_Tinh_Steel" title="Formosa Ha Tinh Steel">Formosa Ha Tinh Steel</a> Company illegally discharging toxic industrial waste into the ocean. This killed many fish and destroyed marine habitats in Vietnamese waters, resulting in major losses to the country's economy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETiezzi2016_405-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETiezzi2016-405">[397]</a></sup> The government is intervening and attempting solutions to decrease air pollution by decreasing the number of motorcycles while increasing public transportation. It has introduced more regulations for <a href="/wiki/Waste" title="Waste">waste</a> handling by factories. Although the authorities also have schedules for collecting different types of waste, waste disposal is another problem caused by urbanisation. The amount of solid waste generated in urban areas of Vietnam has increased by more than 200% from 2003 to 2008. Industrial solid waste accounted for 181% of that increase. One of the government's efforts includes attempting to promote campaigns that encourage locals to sort <a href="/wiki/Municipal_solid_waste" title="Municipal solid waste">household waste</a>, since <a href="/wiki/Waste_sorting" title="Waste sorting">waste sorting</a> is still not practised by most of Vietnamese society.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETrương201819_406-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrương201819-406">[398]</a></sup>
</p>
<div>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Vietnam" title="Religion in Vietnam">Religion in Vietnam</a></div>
<div class="PieChartTemplate thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px">
<div class="mw-no-invert" style="background-color:white;margin:auto;position:relative;width:200px;height:200px;overflow:hidden;border-radius:100px;border:1px solid black;transform:scaleX(-1)rotate(-90deg)">
<div style="border:solid transparent;background-color: initial;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:0; top:0; border-width:0 200px 200px 0; border-color:#fcf7f7"></div><div style="border:solid transparent;background-color: initial;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 13262.66059596px; border-left-color:#FF6600"></div>
<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:#FF6600"></div>
<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:#FF6600"></div><div style="border:solid transparent;background-color: initial;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 8376.1780133552px; border-left-color:#b3ff9e"></div>
<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:#b3ff9e"></div>
<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:#b3ff9e"></div><div style="border:solid transparent;background-color: initial;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 2065.3343769455px; border-left-color:#fffa75"></div>
<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:#fffa75"></div>

<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:#87CEFA"></div>

<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:#edb7e9"></div>
