<div class="thumbcaption">
<p>Religion in Vietnam (2019)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGeneral_Statistics_Office_of_Vietnam2019_3-7"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGeneral_Statistics_Office_of_Vietnam2019-3">[2]</a></sup>
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r981673959">.mw-parser-output .legend{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .legend-color{display:inline-block;min-width:1.25em;height:1.25em;line-height:1.25;margin:1px 0;text-align:center;border:1px solid black;background-color:transparent;color:black}.mw-parser-output .legend-text{}</style><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#e3ffff; color:black;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_folk_religion" title="Vietnamese folk religion">Vietnamese folk religion</a> or no religion (86.32%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#ffdab0; color:black;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Vietnam" title="Buddhism in Vietnam">Buddhism</a> (4.79%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#edb7e9; color:black;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_Vietnam" title="Catholic Church in Vietnam">Catholicism</a> (6.1%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#87CEFA; color:black;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Protestantism_in_Vietnam" title="Protestantism in Vietnam">Protestantism</a> (1.0%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#fffa75; color:black;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/H%C3%B2a_H%E1%BA%A3o" title="Hòa Hảo">Hoahaoism</a> (1.02%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#b3ff9e; color:black;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Caodaism" title="Caodaism">Caodaism</a> (0.58%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#FF6600; color:black;"> </span> Islam (0.07%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#fcf7f7; color:black;"> </span> Others (0.12%)</div>
</div>
</div></div>
<p>Under Article 70 of the 1992 Constitution of Vietnam, all citizens enjoy <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_religion" title="Freedom of religion">freedom of belief and religion</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Vietnam1992_414-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Vietnam1992-414">[405]</a></sup> All religions are equal before the law and each <a href="/wiki/Place_of_worship" title="Place of worship">place of worship</a> is protected under Vietnamese state law. Religious beliefs cannot be misused to undermine state law and policies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Vietnam1992_414-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Vietnam1992-414">[405]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Ordinance_of_Beliefs_and_Religion2004_415-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Ordinance_of_Beliefs_and_Religion2004-415">[406]</a></sup> According to a 2007 survey 81% of Vietnamese people <a href="/wiki/Atheism" title="Atheism">did not believe in a god</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEZuckerman200711_416-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEZuckerman200711-416">[407]</a></sup> Based on government findings in 2009, the number of religious people increased by 932,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_General_Statistics_Office2009a_417-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_General_Statistics_Office2009a-417">[408]</a></sup> The official statistics, presented by the Vietnamese government to the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_special_rapporteur" title="United Nations special rapporteur">United Nations special rapporteur</a> in 2014, indicate the overall number of followers of recognised religions is about 24 million of a total population of almost 90 million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBielefeldt2014_418-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBielefeldt2014-418">[409]</a></sup> According to the General Statistics Office of Vietnam in 2019, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Vietnam" title="Buddhism in Vietnam">Buddhists</a> account for 4.79% of the total population, <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_Vietnam" title="Catholic Church in Vietnam">Catholics</a> 6.1%, <a href="/wiki/Protestantism_in_Vietnam" title="Protestantism in Vietnam">Protestants</a> 1.0%, <a href="/wiki/H%C3%B2a_H%E1%BA%A3o" title="Hòa Hảo">Hoahao Buddhists</a> 1.02%, and <a href="/wiki/Caodaism" title="Caodaism">Caodaism</a> followers 0.58%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGeneral_Statistics_Office_of_Vietnam2019_3-8"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGeneral_Statistics_Office_of_Vietnam2019-3">[2]</a></sup> Other religions includes <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%CA%BC%C3%AD_Faith" title="Baháʼí Faith">Bahaʼís</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Hinduism</a>, representing less than 0.2% of the population.
</p><p>The majority of Vietnamese do not follow any organised religion, though many of them observe some form of <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_folk_religion" title="Vietnamese folk religion">Vietnamese folk religion</a>. <a href="/wiki/Confucianism" title="Confucianism">Confucianism</a> as a system of social and ethical philosophy still has certain influences in modern Vietnam. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mah%C4%81y%C4%81na_Buddhism" title="Mahāyāna Buddhism">Mahāyāna</a> is the dominant branch of Buddhism, while <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Therav%C4%81da_Buddhism" title="Theravāda Buddhism">Theravāda</a> is practised mostly by the Khmer minority. About 8 to 9% of the population is Christian—made up of Roman Catholics and Protestants. Catholicism was introduced to Vietnam in the 16th century and was firmly established by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Society_of_Jesus" title="Society of Jesus">Jesuits</a> missionaries (mainly <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_people" title="Portuguese people">Portuguese</a> and <a href="/wiki/Italians" title="Italians">Italian</a>) in the 17th centuries from nearby <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Macau" title="Portuguese Macau">Portuguese Macau</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETran2018_75-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETran2018-75">[69]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/French_people" title="French people">French</a> missionaries (from the <a href="/wiki/Paris_Foreign_Missions_Society" title="Paris Foreign Missions Society">Paris Foreign Missions Society</a>) together with <a href="/wiki/Spaniards" title="Spaniards">Spanish</a> missionaries (from the <a href="/wiki/Dominican_Order" title="Dominican Order">Dominican Order</a> of the neighbouring <a href="/wiki/Spanish_East_Indies" title="Spanish East Indies">Spanish East Indies</a>) actively sought converts in the 18th, 19th, and first half of the 20th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWoods200234_419-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWoods200234-419">[410]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeith201242,_72_420-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeith201242,_72-420">[411]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELamport2018898_421-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELamport2018898-421">[412]</a></sup> A significant number of Vietnamese people, especially in the South, are also adherents of two indigenous religions of syncretic <a href="/wiki/Caodaism" title="Caodaism">Caodaism</a> and quasi-Buddhist <a href="/wiki/H%C3%B2a_H%E1%BA%A3o" title="Hòa Hảo">Hoahaoism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELargo2002168_422-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELargo2002168-422">[413]</a></sup> Protestantism was only recently spread by American and Canadian missionaries in the 20th century;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVan_Hoang20171_423-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVan_Hoang20171-423">[414]</a></sup> the largest Protestant denomination is the <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Evangelical_Church_of_Vietnam_%E2%80%93_South&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Evangelical Church of Vietnam – South (page does not exist)">Evangelical Church of Vietnam</a>. Around 770,000 of the country's Protestants are members of ethnic minorities,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVan_Hoang20171_423-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVan_Hoang20171-423">[414]</a></sup> particularly the highland <a href="/wiki/Montagnard_(Vietnam)" title="Montagnard (Vietnam)">Montagnards</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECultural_Orientation_Resource_Centre5,_7_424-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECultural_Orientation_Resource_Centre5,_7-424">[415]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Hmong_people" title="Hmong people">Hmong people</a>. Although it is one of the country's minority religions, Protestantism is the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fastest-growing_religion" title="Fastest-growing religion">fastest-growing religion</a> in Vietnam, expanding at a rate of 600% in recent decades.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVan_Hoang20171_423-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVan_Hoang20171-423">[414]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnited_States_Department_of_State2005_425-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnited_States_Department_of_State2005-425">[416]</a></sup> Several other minority faiths exist in Vietnam, these include: Bani, <a href="/wiki/Sunni_Islam" title="Sunni Islam">Sunni</a> and <a href="/wiki/Non-denominational_Muslim" title="Non-denominational Muslim">non-denominational</a> sections of Islam which is practised primarily among the ethnic <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cham_people" title="Cham people">Cham</a> minority.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKỳ_PhươngLockhart201135_426-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKỳ_PhươngLockhart201135-426">[417]</a></sup> There are also a few Kinh adherents of Islam, other minority adherents of Baha'i, as well as <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Southeast_Asia#Vietnam" title="Hinduism in Southeast Asia">Hindus among the Cham</a>'s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELevinsonChristensen200289_427-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELevinsonChristensen200289-427">[418]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESharma200948_428-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma200948-428">[419]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">Languages</span></h3>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/National_language" title="National language">national language</a> of the country is <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_language" title="Vietnamese language">Vietnamese</a>, a tonal <a href="/wiki/Austroasiatic_languages" title="Austroasiatic languages">Austroasiatic language</a> (Mon–Khmer), which is spoken by the majority of the population. In its early history, Vietnamese writing used <a href="/wiki/Chinese_characters" title="Chinese characters">Chinese characters</a> (<span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi">chữ Hán</i></span>) before a different meaning set of Chinese characters known as <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi"><a href="/wiki/Ch%E1%BB%AF_N%C3%B4m" title="Chữ Nôm">chữ Nôm</a></i></span> developed between the 7th–13th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEZwartjes2011292_429-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEZwartjes2011292-429">[420]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChoy2013340_430-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChoy2013340-430">[421]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDinh_Tham201867_431-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDinh_Tham201867-431">[422]</a></sup> The folk epic <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi"><a href="/wiki/The_Tale_of_Kieu" title="The Tale of Kieu">Truyện Kiều</a></i></span> (<i>The Tale of Kieu</i>, originally known as <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi">Đoạn trường tân thanh</i></span>) by <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><span lang="vi" style="font-style: normal;"><a href="/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_Du" title="Nguyễn Du">Nguyễn Du</a></span></span> was written in <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi">chữ Nôm</i></span>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOzolinš2016130_432-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOzolinš2016130-432">[423]</a></sup> <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi"><a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_alphabet" title="Vietnamese alphabet">Chữ Quốc ngữ</a></i></span>, the Romanised Vietnamese alphabet, was developed in the 17th century by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Society_of_Jesus" title="Society of Jesus">Jesuit</a> missionaries such as <a href="/wiki/Francisco_de_Pina" title="Francisco de Pina">Francisco de Pina</a> and <a href="/wiki/Alexandre_de_Rhodes" title="Alexandre de Rhodes">Alexandre de Rhodes</a> by using the alphabets of the <a href="/wiki/Romance_languages" title="Romance languages">Romance languages</a>, particularly the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Portuguese_alphabet" title="Portuguese alphabet">Portuguese alphabet</a>, which later became widely used through Vietnamese institutions during the French colonial period.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEZwartjes2011292_429-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEZwartjes2011292-429">[420]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJacques199821_433-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJacques199821-433">[424]</a></sup>
</p><p>Vietnam's minority groups speak a variety of languages, including: <a href="/wiki/T%C3%A0y_language" title="Tày language">Tày</a>, <a href="/wiki/Muong_language" title="Muong language">Mường</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cham_language" title="Cham language">Cham</a>, <a href="/wiki/Khmer_language" title="Khmer language">Khmer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chinese_language" title="Chinese language">Chinese</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nung_language_(Tai)" title="Nung language (Tai)">Nùng</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hmong_language" title="Hmong language">Hmong</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Montagnard_(Vietnam)" title="Montagnard (Vietnam)">Montagnard</a> peoples of the <a href="/wiki/Central_Highlands_(Vietnam)" title="Central Highlands (Vietnam)">Central Highlands</a> also speak a number of distinct languages, some belonging to the Austroasiatic and others to the <a href="/wiki/Malayo-Polynesian_languages" title="Malayo-Polynesian languages">Malayo-Polynesian</a> language families.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECultural_Orientation_Resource_Centre10_434-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECultural_Orientation_Resource_Centre10-434">[425]</a></sup> In recent years, a number of <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_sign_languages" title="Vietnamese sign languages">sign languages</a> have developed in the major cities.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vietnamese_calligraphy.jpg"><img alt="A sample of traditional Vietnamese calligraphy" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="505" data-file-width="760" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Vietnamese_calligraphy.jpg/220px-Vietnamese_calligraphy.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Vietnamese_calligraphy.jpg/330px-Vietnamese_calligraphy.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Vietnamese_calligraphy.jpg/440px-Vietnamese_calligraphy.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Vietnamese_calligraphy.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_calligraphy" title="Vietnamese calligraphy">Vietnamese calligraphy</a> in Latin alphabet.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">French language</a>, a legacy of colonial rule, is spoken by many educated Vietnamese as a second language, especially among the older generation and those educated in the former <a href="/wiki/South_Vietnam" title="South Vietnam">South Vietnam</a>, where it was a principal language in administration, education and commerce. Vietnam remains a full member of the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_internationale_de_la_Francophonie" title="Organisation internationale de la Francophonie">International Organisation of the Francophonie</a> (<span title="French-language text"><i lang="fr">La Francophonie</i></span>) and education has revived some interest in the language.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFrench_Senate1997_435-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFrench_Senate1997-435">[426]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Russian_language" title="Russian language">Russian</a>, and to a lesser extent <a href="/wiki/German_language" title="German language">German</a>, <a href="/wiki/Czech_language" title="Czech language">Czech</a> and <a href="/wiki/Polish_language" title="Polish language">Polish</a> are known among some northern Vietnamese whose families had ties with the Eastern Bloc during the Cold War.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVan_Van8_436-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVan_Van8-436">[427]</a></sup> With improved relations with Western countries and recent reforms in Vietnamese administration, <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">English</a> has been increasingly used as a second language and the study of English is now obligatory in most schools either alongside or in place of French.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVan_Van9_437-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVan_Van9-437">[428]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnited_Kingdom_Department_for_International_Trade2018_438-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnited_Kingdom_Department_for_International_Trade2018-438">[429]</a></sup> The popularity of <a href="/wiki/Japanese_language" title="Japanese language">Japanese</a>, <a href="/wiki/Korean_language" title="Korean language">Korean</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mandarin_Chinese" title="Mandarin Chinese">Mandarin Chinese</a> have also grown as the country's ties with other <a href="/wiki/East_Asia" title="East Asia">East Asian</a> nations have strengthened.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWai-ming20023_439-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWai-ming20023-439">[430]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAnh_Dinh201663_440-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAnh_Dinh201663-440">[431]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHirano2016_441-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHirano2016-441">[432]</a></sup> Third-graders can choose one of seven languages (English, Russian, French, Chinese, Japanese, Korean, German) as their first foreign language.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-442"><a href="#cite_note-442">[433]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-443"><a href="#cite_note-443">[434]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-444"><a href="#cite_note-444">[435]</a></sup> In Vietnam's <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Vietnam" title="Education in Vietnam">high school graduation examinations</a>, students can take their foreign language exam in one of the above-mentioned languages.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-445"><a href="#cite_note-445">[436]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Vietnam" title="Culture of Vietnam">Culture of Vietnam</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tleft"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hanoi_Temple_of_Literature.jpg"><img alt="The Temple of Literature in Hanoi" data-file-height="1944" data-file-width="2592" decoding="async" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Hanoi_Temple_of_Literature.jpg/200px-Hanoi_Temple_of_Literature.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Hanoi_Temple_of_Literature.jpg/300px-Hanoi_Temple_of_Literature.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Hanoi_Temple_of_Literature.jpg/400px-Hanoi_Temple_of_Literature.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Temple_of_Literature" title="Temple of Literature">Temple of Literature</a> in Hanoi</div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hue_Vietnam_Citadel-of-Hu%E1%BA%BF-01.jpg"><img alt="The Meridian Gate (Huế)" data-file-height="2555" data-file-width="3833" decoding="async" height="133" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Hue_Vietnam_Citadel-of-Hu%E1%BA%BF-01.jpg/200px-Hue_Vietnam_Citadel-of-Hu%E1%BA%BF-01.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Hue_Vietnam_Citadel-of-Hu%E1%BA%BF-01.jpg/300px-Hue_Vietnam_Citadel-of-Hu%E1%BA%BF-01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Hue_Vietnam_Citadel-of-Hu%E1%BA%BF-01.jpg/400px-Hue_Vietnam_Citadel-of-Hu%E1%BA%BF-01.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Imperial_City_of_Hu%E1%BA%BF" title="Imperial City of Huế">Imperial City of Huế</a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%C3%93pera,_Ciudad_Ho_Chi_Minh,_Vietnam,_2013-08-14,_DD_02.JPG"><img alt="The Municipal Theatre in Ho Chi Minh City" data-file-height="3101" data-file-width="5114" decoding="async" height="121" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/%C3%93pera%2C_Ciudad_Ho_Chi_Minh%2C_Vietnam%2C_2013-08-14%2C_DD_02.JPG/200px-%C3%93pera%2C_Ciudad_Ho_Chi_Minh%2C_Vietnam%2C_2013-08-14%2C_DD_02.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/%C3%93pera%2C_Ciudad_Ho_Chi_Minh%2C_Vietnam%2C_2013-08-14%2C_DD_02.JPG/300px-%C3%93pera%2C_Ciudad_Ho_Chi_Minh%2C_Vietnam%2C_2013-08-14%2C_DD_02.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/%C3%93pera%2C_Ciudad_Ho_Chi_Minh%2C_Vietnam%2C_2013-08-14%2C_DD_02.JPG/400px-%C3%93pera%2C_Ciudad_Ho_Chi_Minh%2C_Vietnam%2C_2013-08-14%2C_DD_02.JPG 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Municipal_Theatre,_Ho_Chi_Minh_City" title="Municipal Theatre, Ho Chi Minh City">Municipal Theatre</a> (Saigon Opera House) in Ho Chi Minh City</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Vietnam's culture has developed over the centuries from indigenous ancient <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C4%90%C3%B4ng_S%C6%A1n_culture" title="Đông Sơn culture">Đông Sơn culture</a> with wet rice cultivation as its economic base.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHigham1984_39-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHigham1984-39">[33]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECalò200951_42-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECalò200951-42">[36]</a></sup> Some elements of the nation's culture have Chinese origins, drawing on elements of <a href="/wiki/Confucianism" title="Confucianism">Confucianism</a>, Mahāyāna Buddhism and <a href="/wiki/Taoism" title="Taoism">Taoism</a> in its traditional political system and philosophy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETung_Hieu201571_446-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETung_Hieu201571-446">[437]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENhu_Nguyen201632_447-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENhu_Nguyen201632-447">[438]</a></sup> Vietnamese society is structured around <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi">làng</i></span> (ancestral villages);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEndres2001_448-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEndres2001-448">[439]</a></sup> all Vietnamese mark a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gi%E1%BB%97_T%E1%BB%95_H%C3%B9ng_V%C6%B0%C6%A1ng" title="Giỗ Tổ Hùng Vương">common ancestral anniversary</a> on the tenth day of the third <a href="/wiki/Lunar_calendar" title="Lunar calendar">lunar month</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGrigoreva20144_449-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGrigoreva20144-449">[440]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUNESCO_Intangible_Cultural_Heritage2012_450-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUNESCO_Intangible_Cultural_Heritage2012-450">[441]</a></sup> The influence of <a href="/wiki/Chinese_culture" title="Chinese culture">Chinese culture</a> such as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cantonese_culture" title="Cantonese culture">Cantonese</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hakka_culture" title="Hakka culture">Hakka</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hokkien_culture" title="Hokkien culture">Hokkien</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hainan" title="Hainan">Hainanese</a> cultures is more evident in the north where Buddhism is strongly entwined with popular culture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEZhuRenCollinsWarner2017142_451-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEZhuRenCollinsWarner2017142-451">[442]</a></sup> Despite this, there are <a href="/wiki/Chinatown" title="Chinatown">Chinatowns</a> in the south, such as in <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><span lang="vi" style="font-style: normal;"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ch%E1%BB%A3_L%E1%BB%9Bn,_Ho_Chi_Minh_City" title="Chợ Lớn, Ho Chi Minh City">Chợ Lớn</a></span></span>, where many Chinese have <a href="/wiki/Interracial_marriage" title="Interracial marriage">intermarried</a> with Kinh and are indistinguishable among them.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcLeodThi_Dieu20018_452-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcLeodThi_Dieu20018-452">[443]</a></sup> In the central and southern parts of Vietnam, traces of Champa and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Khmer_culture" title="Khmer culture">Khmer culture</a> are evidenced through the remains of ruins, artefacts as well within their population as the successor of the ancient <a href="/wiki/Sa_Hu%E1%BB%B3nh_culture" title="Sa Huỳnh culture">Sa Huỳnh culture</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMomoki199636_453-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMomoki199636-453">[444]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKỳ_PhươngLockhart201184_454-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKỳ_PhươngLockhart201184-454">[445]</a></sup> In recent centuries, Western cultures have become popular among recent generations of Vietnamese.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENhu_Nguyen201632_447-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENhu_Nguyen201632-447">[438]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ao-dai-xu-Hue-2.jpg"><img alt="Photograph of two girls wearing a traditional Vietnamese white school uniform, the áo dài—both are holding the nón lá, a conical hat" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="601" data-file-width="400" decoding="async" height="255" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Ao-dai-xu-Hue-2.jpg/170px-Ao-dai-xu-Hue-2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Ao-dai-xu-Hue-2.jpg/255px-Ao-dai-xu-Hue-2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Ao-dai-xu-Hue-2.jpg/340px-Ao-dai-xu-Hue-2.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ao-dai-xu-Hue-2.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Vietnamese traditional white <a href="/wiki/School_uniforms_by_country#Vietnam" title="School uniforms by country">school uniform</a> for girls in the country, the <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi"><a href="/wiki/%C3%81o_d%C3%A0i" title="Áo dài">áo dài</a></i></span> with the addition of <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi"><a href="/wiki/Asian_conical_hat" title="Asian conical hat">nón lá</a></i></span>, a conical hat.</div></div></div>
<p>The traditional focuses of Vietnamese culture are based on humanity (<span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi">nhân nghĩa</i></span>) and harmony (<span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi">hòa</i></span>) in which family and community values are highly regarded.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEZhuRenCollinsWarner2017142_451-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEZhuRenCollinsWarner2017142-451">[442]</a></sup> Vietnam reveres a number of key cultural symbols,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVo201296_455-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVo201296-455">[446]</a></sup> such as the <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_dragon" title="Vietnamese dragon">Vietnamese dragon</a> which is derived from <a href="/wiki/Crocodile" title="Crocodile">crocodile</a> and <a href="/wiki/Snake" title="Snake">snake</a> imagery; Vietnam's national father, <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><span lang="vi" style="font-style: normal;"><a href="/wiki/L%E1%BA%A1c_Long_Qu%C3%A2n" title="Lạc Long Quân">Lạc Long Quân</a></span></span> is depicted as a holy dragon.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGrigoreva20144_449-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGrigoreva20144-449">[440]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGallop2017_456-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGallop2017-456">[447]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnamese-American_Association_457-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnamese-American_Association-457">[448]</a></sup> The <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi">lạc</i></span> is a holy bird representing Vietnam's national mother <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><span lang="vi" style="font-style: normal;"><a href="/wiki/%C3%82u_C%C6%A1" title="Âu Cơ">Âu Cơ</a></span></span>. Other prominent images that are also revered are the <a href="/wiki/Turtle" title="Turtle">turtle</a>, <a href="/wiki/Water_buffalo" title="Water buffalo">buffalo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Horse" title="Horse">horse</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChonchirdsin2016_458-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChonchirdsin2016-458">[449]</a></sup> Many Vietnamese also believe in the <a href="/wiki/Supernatural" title="Supernatural">supernatural</a> and <a href="/wiki/Spiritualism" title="Spiritualism">spiritualism</a> where illness can be brought on by a <a href="/wiki/Curse" title="Curse">curse</a> or <a href="/wiki/Witchcraft" title="Witchcraft">sorcery</a> or caused by non-observance of a religious ethic. Traditional medical practitioners, <a href="/wiki/Amulet" title="Amulet">amulets</a> and other forms of spiritual protection and religious practices may be employed to treat the ill person.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWaitemata_District_Health_Board20152_459-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWaitemata_District_Health_Board20152-459">[450]</a></sup> In the modern era, the cultural life of Vietnam has been deeply influenced by government-controlled media and cultural programs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENhu_Nguyen201632_447-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENhu_Nguyen201632-447">[438]</a></sup> For many decades, foreign cultural influences, especially those of Western origin, were shunned. But since the recent reformation, Vietnam has seen a greater exposure to neighbouring Southeast Asian, East Asian as well to Western culture and media.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPhuong2012_460-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPhuong2012-460">[451]</a></sup>
</p><p>The main Vietnamese formal dress, the <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi"><a href="/wiki/%C3%81o_d%C3%A0i" title="Áo dài">áo dài</a></i></span> is worn for special occasions such as weddings and religious festivals. White <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi">áo dài</i></span> is the required uniform for girls in many high schools across the country. Other examples of traditional Vietnamese clothing include: the <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi"><a href="/wiki/%C3%81o_t%E1%BB%A9_th%C3%A2n" title="Áo tứ thân">áo tứ thân</a></i></span>, a four-piece woman's dress; the <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi">áo ngũ</i></span>, a form of the <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi">thân</i></span> in five-piece form, mostly worn in the north of the country; the <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi"><a href="/wiki/Y%E1%BA%BFm" title="Yếm">yếm</a></i></span>, a woman's undergarment; the <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi"><a href="/wiki/%C3%81o_b%C3%A0_ba" title="Áo bà ba">áo bà ba</a></i></span>, rural working "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pyjamas" title="Pyjamas">pyjamas</a>" for men and women; the <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi"><a href="/wiki/%C3%81o_g%E1%BA%A5m" title="Áo gấm">áo gấm</a></i></span>, a formal brocade tunic for government receptions; and the <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi">áo the</i></span>, a variant of the <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi">áo gấm</i></span> worn by grooms at weddings.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewandowski201112_461-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewandowski201112-461">[452]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHoward201690_462-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHoward201690-462">[453]</a></sup> Traditional headwear includes the standard conical <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi"><a href="/wiki/N%C3%B3n_l%C3%A1" title="Nón lá">nón lá</a></i></span> and the "lampshade-like" <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/N%C3%B3n_quai_thao" title="Nón quai thao">nón quai thao</a></i></span>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHoward201690_462-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHoward201690-462">[453]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChico2013354_463-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChico2013354-463">[454]</a></sup> In tourism, a number of popular cultural tourist destinations include the former <a href="/wiki/Imperial_City_of_Hu%E1%BA%BF" title="Imperial City of Huế">Imperial City of Huế</a>, the <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Sites</a> of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Phong_Nha-K%E1%BA%BB_B%C3%A0ng_National_Park" title="Phong Nha-Kẻ Bàng National Park">Phong Nha-Kẻ Bàng National Park</a>, <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><span lang="vi" style="font-style: normal;"><a href="/wiki/H%E1%BB%99i_An" title="Hội An">Hội An</a></span></span> and <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><span lang="vi" style="font-style: normal;"><a href="/wiki/M%E1%BB%B9_S%C6%A1n" title="Mỹ Sơn">Mỹ Sơn</a></span></span>, coastal regions such as Nha Trang, the caves of Hạ Long Bay and the <a href="/wiki/Marble_Mountains_(Vietnam)" title="Marble Mountains (Vietnam)">Marble Mountains</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPha_Le2014_464-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPha_Le2014-464">[455]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Net2017a_465-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Net2017a-465">[456]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">Literature</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_literature" title="Vietnamese literature">Vietnamese literature</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_poetry" title="Vietnamese poetry">Vietnamese poetry</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_fairy_tales" title="Vietnamese fairy tales">Vietnamese fairy tales</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Dragon_on_Emperor_Kh%E1%BA%A3i_%C4%90%E1%BB%8Bnh%E2%80%99s_scroll,_1917_(British_Library).png"><img alt="A scroll showing a Vietnamese dragon" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="503" data-file-width="1024" decoding="async" height="123" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Dragon_on_Emperor_Kh%E1%BA%A3i_%C4%90%E1%BB%8Bnh%E2%80%99s_scroll%2C_1917_%28British_Library%29.png/250px-Dragon_on_Emperor_Kh%E1%BA%A3i_%C4%90%E1%BB%8Bnh%E2%80%99s_scroll%2C_1917_%28British_Library%29.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Dragon_on_Emperor_Kh%E1%BA%A3i_%C4%90%E1%BB%8Bnh%E2%80%99s_scroll%2C_1917_%28British_Library%29.png/375px-Dragon_on_Emperor_Kh%E1%BA%A3i_%C4%90%E1%BB%8Bnh%E2%80%99s_scroll%2C_1917_%28British_Library%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Dragon_on_Emperor_Kh%E1%BA%A3i_%C4%90%E1%BB%8Bnh%E2%80%99s_scroll%2C_1917_%28British_Library%29.png/500px-Dragon_on_Emperor_Kh%E1%BA%A3i_%C4%90%E1%BB%8Bnh%E2%80%99s_scroll%2C_1917_%28British_Library%29.png 2x" width="250"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Dragon_on_Emperor_Kh%E1%BA%A3i_%C4%90%E1%BB%8Bnh%E2%80%99s_scroll,_1917_(British_Library).png" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_dragon" title="Vietnamese dragon">Vietnamese dragon</a> on Emperor <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><span lang="vi" style="font-style: normal;"><a href="/wiki/Kh%E1%BA%A3i_%C4%90%E1%BB%8Bnh" title="Khải Định">Khải Định</a></span></span>'s <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 1917</span> scroll in <a href="/wiki/British_Library" title="British Library">British Library</a> collection.</div></div></div>
<p>Vietnamese literature has centuries-deep history and the country has a rich tradition of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Folk_literature" title="Folk literature">folk literature</a> based on the typical six–to-eight-verse poetic form called <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi">ca dao</i></span> which usually focuses on village ancestors and heroes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHuong2010_466-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHuong2010-466">[457]</a></sup> Written literature has been found dating back to the 10th century <a href="/wiki/Ng%C3%B4_dynasty" title="Ngô dynasty">Ngô dynasty</a>, with notable ancient authors including: <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><span lang="vi" style="font-style: normal;"><a href="/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_Tr%C3%A3i" title="Nguyễn Trãi">Nguyễn Trãi</a></span></span>, <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><span lang="vi" style="font-style: normal;"><a href="/wiki/Tr%E1%BA%A7n_H%C6%B0ng_%C4%90%E1%BA%A1o" title="Trần Hưng Đạo">Trần Hưng Đạo</a></span></span>, <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><span lang="vi" style="font-style: normal;"><a href="/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_Du" title="Nguyễn Du">Nguyễn Du</a></span></span> and <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><span lang="vi" style="font-style: normal;"><a href="/wiki/Nguy%E1%BB%85n_%C4%90%C3%ACnh_Chi%E1%BB%83u" title="Nguyễn Đình Chiểu">Nguyễn Đình Chiểu</a></span></span>. Some literary genres play an important role in theatrical performance, such as <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi">hát nói</i></span> in <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi"><a href="/wiki/Ca_tr%C3%B9" title="Ca trù">ca trù</a></i></span>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENorton2015_467-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENorton2015-467">[458]</a></sup> Some poetic unions have also been formed in Vietnam, such as the <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi">tao đàn</i></span>. Vietnamese literature has been influenced by Western styles in recent times, with the first literary transformation movement of <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi"><a href="/wiki/Th%C6%A1_m%E1%BB%9Bi" title="Thơ mới">thơ mới</a></i></span> emerging in 1932.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELe2008_468-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELe2008-468">[459]</a></sup> Vietnamese folk literature is an intermingling of many forms. It is not only an oral tradition, but a mixing of three media: hidden (only retained in the memory of folk authors), fixed (written), and shown (performed). Folk literature usually exists in many versions, passed down orally, and has unknown authors. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Myths" title="Myths">Myths</a> consist of stories about supernatural beings, heroes, creator gods and reflect the viewpoint of ancient people about human life.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVo20124_469-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVo20124-469">[460]</a></sup> They consist of creation stories, stories about their origins (<span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi">Lạc Long Quân</i></span> and <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi">Âu Cơ</i></span>), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Culture_heroes" title="Culture heroes">culture heroes</a> (<a href="/wiki/S%C6%A1n_Tinh_%E2%80%93_Th%E1%BB%A7y_Tinh" title="Sơn Tinh – Thủy Tinh"><span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi">Sơn Tinh</i></span> and <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi">Thủy Tinh</i></span></a>) which are referred to as a mountain and water spirit respectively and many other folklore tales.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcLeodThi_Dieu20018_452-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcLeodThi_Dieu20018-452">[443]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETranLe20175_470-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETranLe20175-470">[461]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music">Music</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Vietnam" title="Music of Vietnam">Music of Vietnam</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ca_tr%C3%B9_performance.jpg"><img alt="Three musicians are performing on a stage." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1135" data-file-width="1545" decoding="async" height="162" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Ca_tr%C3%B9_performance.jpg/220px-Ca_tr%C3%B9_performance.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Ca_tr%C3%B9_performance.jpg/330px-Ca_tr%C3%B9_performance.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Ca_tr%C3%B9_performance.jpg/440px-Ca_tr%C3%B9_performance.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ca_tr%C3%B9_performance.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi"><a href="/wiki/Ca_tr%C3%B9" title="Ca trù">Ca trù</a></i></span> trio performance in northern Vietnam</div></div></div>
<p>Traditional Vietnamese music varies between the country's northern and southern regions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETrần1972_471-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrần1972-471">[462]</a></sup> Northern classical music is Vietnam's oldest musical form and is traditionally more formal. The origins of Vietnamese classical music can be traced to the Mongol invasions in the 13th century when the Vietnamese captured a <a href="/wiki/Chinese_opera" title="Chinese opera">Chinese opera</a> troupe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiettinen1992163_472-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiettinen1992163-472">[463]</a></sup> Throughout its history, Vietnam has been the most heavily impacted by the <a href="/wiki/Music_of_China" title="Music of China">Chinese musical tradition</a> along with those of Japan, <a href="/wiki/Korea" title="Korea">Korea</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mongolia" title="Mongolia">Mongolia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETrần1985_473-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrần1985-473">[464]</a></sup> <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi"><a href="/wiki/Nh%C3%A3_nh%E1%BA%A1c" title="Nhã nhạc">Nhã nhạc</a></i></span> is the most popular form of imperial court music, <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi"><a href="/wiki/Ch%C3%A8o" title="Chèo">Chèo</a></i></span> is a form of generally satirical <a href="/wiki/Musical_theatre" title="Musical theatre">musical theatre</a>, while <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi"><a href="/wiki/X%E1%BA%A9m" title="Xẩm">Xẩm</a></i></span> or <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi">hát xẩm</i></span> (<span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi">xẩm</i></span> singing) is a type of Vietnamese <a href="/wiki/Folk_music" title="Folk music">folk music</a>. <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi"><a href="/wiki/Quan_h%E1%BB%8D" title="Quan họ">Quan họ</a></i></span> (alternate singing) is popular in the former <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/H%C3%A0_B%E1%BA%AFc_Province" title="Hà Bắc Province">Hà Bắc Province</a> (which is now divided into <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><span lang="vi" style="font-style: normal;"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/B%E1%BA%AFc_Ninh_Province" title="Bắc Ninh Province">Bắc Ninh</a></span></span> and <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><span lang="vi" style="font-style: normal;"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/B%E1%BA%AFc_Giang_Province" title="Bắc Giang Province">Bắc Giang</a></span></span> Provinces) and across Vietnam. Another form of music called <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hat_chau_van" title="Hat chau van">Hát chầu văn</a></i></span> or <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi">hát văn</i></span> is used to invoke spirits during ceremonies. <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi"><a href="/wiki/Nh%E1%BA%A1c_d%C3%A2n_t%E1%BB%99c_c%E1%BA%A3i_bi%C3%AAn" title="Nhạc dân tộc cải biên">Nhạc dân tộc cải biên</a></i></span> is a modern form of Vietnamese <a href="/wiki/Folk_music" title="Folk music">folk music</a> which arose in the 1950s, while <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi"><a href="/wiki/Ca_tr%C3%B9" title="Ca trù">ca trù</a></i></span> (also known as <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi">hát ả đào</i></span>) is a popular folk music. <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi">Hò</i></span> can be thought of as the southern style of <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi">Quan họ</i></span>. There is a range of traditional instruments, including the <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi"><a href="/wiki/%C4%90%C3%A0n_b%E1%BA%A7u" title="Đàn bầu">đàn bầu</a></i></span> (a monochord <a href="/wiki/Zither" title="Zither">zither</a>), the <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi"><a href="/wiki/%C4%90%C3%A0n_g%C3%A1o" title="Đàn gáo">đàn gáo</a></i></span> (a two-stringed <a href="/wiki/Fiddle" title="Fiddle">fiddle</a> with coconut body), and the <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi"><a href="/wiki/%C4%90%C3%A0n_nguy%E1%BB%87t" title="Đàn nguyệt">đàn nguyệt</a></i></span> (a two-stringed fretted moon <a href="/wiki/Lute" title="Lute">lute</a>). In recent times, there have been some efforts at mixing Vietnamese traditional music—especially folk music—with modern music to revive and promote national music in the modern context and educate the younger generations about Vietnam's traditional musical instruments and singing styles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVoice_of_Vietnam2018d_474-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVoice_of_Vietnam2018d-474">[465]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Bolero#Vietnam" title="Bolero">Bolero</a> music has gained popularity in the country since the 1930s, albeit with a different style—a combination of traditional Vietnamese music with Western elements.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDuy2016_475-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDuy2016-475">[466]</a></sup> In the 21st century, the modern Vietnamese <a href="/wiki/Pop_music" title="Pop music">pop music</a> industry known as <a href="/wiki/V-pop" title="V-pop">V-pop</a> incorporates elements of many popular genres worldwide, such as <a href="/wiki/Electronic_music" title="Electronic music">electronic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dance_music" title="Dance music">dance</a> and <a href="/wiki/Contemporary_R%26B" title="Contemporary R&amp;B">R&amp;B</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPhương2018_476-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPhương2018-476">[467]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChen2018194_477-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChen2018194-477">[468]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_cuisine" title="Vietnamese cuisine">Vietnamese cuisine</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Cuisine_of_Vietnam.jpg"><img alt="Photographs of a phở noodle dish, a chè thái fruit dessert, a chả giò spring roll and a bánh mì sandwich" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="720" data-file-width="720" decoding="async" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Cuisine_of_Vietnam.jpg/220px-Cuisine_of_Vietnam.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Cuisine_of_Vietnam.jpg/330px-Cuisine_of_Vietnam.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Cuisine_of_Vietnam.jpg/440px-Cuisine_of_Vietnam.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Cuisine_of_Vietnam.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Some of the notable Vietnamese cuisine, clockwise from top-right: <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ph%E1%BB%9F" title="Phở">phở</a></i></span> noodle, <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi">chè thái</i></span> fruit dessert, <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi"><a href="/wiki/Ch%E1%BA%A3_gi%C3%B2" title="Chả giò">chả giò</a></i></span> spring roll and <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi"><a href="/wiki/B%C3%A1nh_m%C3%AC" title="Bánh mì">bánh mì</a></i></span> sandwich.</div></div></div>
<p>Traditionally, Vietnamese cuisine is based around five fundamental taste "elements" (<a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_language" title="Vietnamese language">Vietnamese</a>: <i lang="vi">ngũ vị</i>): spicy (metal), sour (wood), bitter (fire), salty (water) and sweet (earth).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Culture_Information_Network2014_478-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_Culture_Information_Network2014-478">[469]</a></sup> Common ingredients include <a href="/wiki/Fish_sauce" title="Fish sauce">fish sauce</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shrimp_paste" title="Shrimp paste">shrimp paste</a>, <a href="/wiki/Soy_sauce" title="Soy sauce">soy sauce</a>, rice, fresh herbs, fruits and vegetables. Vietnamese recipes use: <a href="/wiki/Cymbopogon" title="Cymbopogon">lemongrass</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ginger" title="Ginger">ginger</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mentha" title="Mentha">mint</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vietnamese_mint" title="Vietnamese mint">Vietnamese mint</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eryngium_foetidum" title="Eryngium foetidum">long coriander</a>, <a href="/wiki/Saigon_cinnamon" title="Saigon cinnamon">Saigon cinnamon</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bird%27s_eye_chilli" title="Bird's eye chilli">bird's eye chilli</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lime_(fruit)" title="Lime (fruit)">lime</a> and <a href="/wiki/Basil" title="Basil">basil</a> leaves.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAustralia_Special_Broadcasting_Service2013_479-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAustralia_Special_Broadcasting_Service2013-479">[470]</a></sup> Traditional Vietnamese cooking is known for its fresh ingredients, minimal use of oil and reliance on herbs and vegetables; it is considered one of the healthiest cuisines worldwide.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECorapi2010_480-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECorapi2010-480">[471]</a></sup> The use of meats such as pork, beef and chicken was relatively limited in the past. Instead freshwater fish, <a href="/wiki/Crustacean" title="Crustacean">crustaceans</a> (particularly <a href="/wiki/Crab" title="Crab">crabs</a>), and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mollusc" title="Mollusc">molluscs</a> became widely used. Fish sauce, soy sauce, prawn sauce and limes are among the main flavouring ingredients. Vietnam has a strong <a href="/wiki/Street_food" title="Street food">street food</a> culture, with 40 popular dishes commonly found throughout the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEClarkMiller2017_481-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEClarkMiller2017-481">[472]</a></sup> Many notable Vietnamese dishes such as <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi"><a href="/wiki/G%E1%BB%8Fi_cu%E1%BB%91n" title="Gỏi cuốn">gỏi cuốn</a></i></span> (salad roll), <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi"><a href="/wiki/B%C3%A1nh_cu%E1%BB%91n" title="Bánh cuốn">bánh cuốn</a></i></span> (rice noodle roll), <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi"><a href="/wiki/B%C3%BAn_ri%C3%AAu" title="Bún riêu">bún riêu</a></i></span> (rice vermicelli soup) and <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ph%E1%BB%9F" title="Phở">phở</a></i></span> noodles originated in the north and were introduced to central and southern Vietnam by northern migrants.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENguyen2011_482-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENguyen2011-482">[473]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThakerBarton2012170_483-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThakerBarton2012170-483">[474]</a></sup> Local foods in the north are often less spicy than southern dishes, as the colder northern climate limits the production and availability of spices.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliams2017_484-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams2017-484">[475]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Black_pepper" title="Black pepper">Black pepper</a> is frequently used in place of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chilli_pepper" title="Chilli pepper">chillis</a> to produce spicy flavours. Vietnamese drinks in the south also are usually served cold with <a href="/wiki/Ice_cube" title="Ice cube">ice cubes</a>, especially during the annual hot seasons; in contrast, in the north hot drinks are more preferable in a colder climate. Some examples of basic Vietnamese drinks include <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi"><a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_iced_coffee" title="Vietnamese iced coffee">cà phê đá</a></i></span> (Vietnamese iced coffee), <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi"><a href="/wiki/Egg_coffee" title="Egg coffee">cà phê trứng</a></i></span> (egg coffee), <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi"><a href="/wiki/Chanh_mu%E1%BB%91i" title="Chanh muối">chanh muối</a></i></span> (salted pickled lime juice), <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi"><a href="/wiki/C%C6%A1m_r%C6%B0%E1%BB%A3u" title="Cơm rượu">cơm rượu</a></i></span> (glutinous rice wine), <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/N%C6%B0%E1%BB%9Bc_m%C3%ADa" title="Nước mía">nước mía</a></i></span> (sugarcane juice) and <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi"><a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_lotus_tea" title="Vietnamese lotus tea">trà sen</a></i></span> (Vietnamese lotus tea).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBatruny2014_485-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBatruny2014-485">[476]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media">Media</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Media_of_Vietnam" title="Media of Vietnam">Media of Vietnam</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vietnam_Television_logo_from_2013.svg"><img alt="Shown is the logo of the state broadcaster Vietnam Television." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="273" data-file-width="663" decoding="async" height="91" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Vietnam_Television_logo_from_2013.svg/220px-Vietnam_Television_logo_from_2013.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Vietnam_Television_logo_from_2013.svg/330px-Vietnam_Television_logo_from_2013.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Vietnam_Television_logo_from_2013.svg/440px-Vietnam_Television_logo_from_2013.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Vietnam_Television_logo_from_2013.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Vietnam_Television" title="Vietnam Television">Vietnam Television</a> (VTV), the main <a href="/wiki/State_media" title="State media">state television</a> station</div></div></div>
<p>Vietnam's media sector is regulated by the government under the 2004 Law on Publication.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVietnam_National_Assembly2004_486-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVietnam_National_Assembly2004-486">[477]</a></sup> It is generally perceived that the country's media sector is controlled by the government and follows the official communist party line, though some newspapers are relatively outspoken.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEXuan_Dinh2000_487-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEXuan_Dinh2000-487">[478]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDattaMendizabal2018_488-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDattaMendizabal2018-488">[479]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Voice_of_Vietnam" title="Voice of Vietnam">Voice of Vietnam</a> (VOV) is the official state-run national radio broadcasting service, broadcasting internationally via shortwave using rented transmitters in other countries and providing broadcasts from its website, while <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_Television" title="Vietnam Television">Vietnam Television</a> (VTV) is the national television broadcasting company. Since 1997, Vietnam has regulated public <a href="/wiki/Internet" title="Internet">internet</a> access extensively using both legal and technical means. The resulting lockdown is widely referred to as the "<a href="/wiki/Internet_censorship_in_Vietnam" title="Internet censorship in Vietnam">Bamboo Firewall</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilkey2002_489-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilkey2002-489">[480]</a></sup> The collaborative project <a href="/wiki/OpenNet_Initiative" title="OpenNet Initiative">OpenNet Initiative</a> classifies Vietnam's level of online political censorship to be "pervasive",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOpenNet_Initiative2012_490-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOpenNet_Initiative2012-490">[481]</a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/Reporters_Without_Borders" title="Reporters Without Borders">Reporters Without Borders</a> (RWB) considers Vietnam to be one of 15 global "internet enemies".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReporters_Without_Borders_491-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReporters_Without_Borders-491">[482]</a></sup> Though the government of Vietnam maintains that such censorship is necessary to safeguard the country against obscene or sexually explicit content, many political and religious websites that are deemed to be undermining state authority are also blocked.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBerkman_Klein_Center2006_492-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBerkman_Klein_Center2006-492">[483]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Holidays_and_festivals">Holidays and festivals</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Public_holidays_in_Vietnam" title="Public holidays in Vietnam">Public holidays in Vietnam</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_traditional_festivals_in_Vietnam" title="List of traditional festivals in Vietnam">List of traditional festivals in Vietnam</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%C4%90%C3%A8n_k%C3%A9o_qu%C3%A2n.jpg"><img alt="A large round white fabric band decorated with red figures and images for Tết" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="768" data-file-width="1024" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/%C4%90%C3%A8n_k%C3%A9o_qu%C3%A2n.jpg/220px-%C4%90%C3%A8n_k%C3%A9o_qu%C3%A2n.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/%C4%90%C3%A8n_k%C3%A9o_qu%C3%A2n.jpg/330px-%C4%90%C3%A8n_k%C3%A9o_qu%C3%A2n.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/%C4%90%C3%A8n_k%C3%A9o_qu%C3%A2n.jpg/440px-%C4%90%C3%A8n_k%C3%A9o_qu%C3%A2n.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%C4%90%C3%A8n_k%C3%A9o_qu%C3%A2n.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Special <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi"><a href="/wiki/T%E1%BA%BFt" title="Tết">Tết</a></i></span> decoration in the country seen during the holiday</div></div></div>
<p>The country has eleven national recognised holidays. These include: <a href="/wiki/New_Year%27s_Day" title="New Year's Day">New Year's Day</a> on 1 January; Vietnamese New Year (<span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi"><a href="/wiki/T%E1%BA%BFt" title="Tết">Tết</a></i></span>) from the last day of the last lunar month to fifth day of the first <a href="/wiki/Lunar_calendar" title="Lunar calendar">lunar month</a>; <a href="/wiki/H%C3%B9ng_Kings%27_Festival" title="Hùng Kings' Festival">Hùng Kings' Festival</a> on the 10th day of the third lunar month; <a href="/wiki/Reunification_Day" title="Reunification Day">Reunification Day</a> on 30 April; <a href="/wiki/International_Workers%27_Day" title="International Workers' Day">International Workers' Day</a> on 1 May; and <a href="/wiki/National_Day_(Vietnam)" title="National Day (Vietnam)">National Day</a> on 2 September.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENational_Congress_of_the_Communist_Party_of_Vietnam2012_493-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENational_Congress_of_the_Communist_Party_of_Vietnam2012-493">[484]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETravel201737_494-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETravel201737-494">[485]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELoan2018_495-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELoan2018-495">[486]</a></sup> During <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi">Tết</i></span>, many Vietnamese from the major cities will return to their villages for family reunions and to pray for dead ancestors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAnh2016b_496-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAnh2016b-496">[487]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETrieu_Dan201792_497-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrieu_Dan201792-497">[488]</a></sup> Older people will usually give the young a <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi"><a href="/wiki/Red_envelope" title="Red envelope">lì xì</a></i></span> (red envelope) while special holiday food, such as <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi"><a href="/wiki/B%C3%A1nh_ch%C6%B0ng" title="Bánh chưng">bánh chưng</a></i></span> (rice cake) in a square shape together with variety of <a href="/wiki/Dried_fruit" title="Dried fruit">dried fruits</a>, are presented in the house for visitors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPike2018_498-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPike2018-498">[489]</a></sup> Many other festivals are celebrated throughout the seasons, including the <a href="/wiki/Lantern_Festival" title="Lantern Festival">Lantern Festival</a> (<span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi">Tết Nguyên Tiêu</i></span>), <a href="/wiki/Mid-Autumn_Festival" title="Mid-Autumn Festival">Mid-Autumn Festival</a> (<span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi">Tết Trung Thu</i></span>) and various temple and nature festivals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETravel201734_499-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETravel201734-499">[490]</a></sup> In the highlands, <a href="/wiki/Elephant_racing" title="Elephant racing">Elephant Race Festivals</a> are held annually during the <a href="/wiki/Spring_(season)" title="Spring (season)">spring</a>; riders will ride their elephants for about 1.6 km (0.99 mi) and the winning elephant will be given sugarcane.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEnglar200623_500-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEnglar200623-500">[491]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Traditional_Vietnamese_wedding" title="Traditional Vietnamese wedding">Traditional Vietnamese weddings</a> remain widely popular and are often celebrated by <a href="/wiki/Overseas_Vietnamese" title="Overseas Vietnamese">expatriate Vietnamese</a> in Western countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAndersonLee2005217_501-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAndersonLee2005217-501">[492]</a></sup> In Vietnam, wedding dress has been influenced by Western styles, with the wearing of white <a href="/wiki/Wedding_dress" title="Wedding dress">wedding dresses</a> and black <a href="/wiki/Black_tie" title="Black tie">jackets</a>; however, there are also many who still prefer to choose Vietnamese traditional wedding costumes for traditional ceremonies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKhanh2008_502-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhanh2008-502">[493]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Vietnam" title="Sport in Vietnam">Sport in Vietnam</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Vietnamese_traditional_games" title="List of Vietnamese traditional games">List of Vietnamese traditional games</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kh%C3%A1n_%C4%91%C3%A0i_B_-_S%C3%A2n_v%E1%BA%ADn_%C4%91%E1%BB%99ng_Qu%E1%BB%91c_gia_M%E1%BB%B9_%C4%90%C3%ACnh.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2304" data-file-width="3072" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Kh%C3%A1n_%C4%91%C3%A0i_B_-_S%C3%A2n_v%E1%BA%ADn_%C4%91%E1%BB%99ng_Qu%E1%BB%91c_gia_M%E1%BB%B9_%C4%90%C3%ACnh.jpg/220px-Kh%C3%A1n_%C4%91%C3%A0i_B_-_S%C3%A2n_v%E1%BA%ADn_%C4%91%E1%BB%99ng_Qu%E1%BB%91c_gia_M%E1%BB%B9_%C4%90%C3%ACnh.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Kh%C3%A1n_%C4%91%C3%A0i_B_-_S%C3%A2n_v%E1%BA%ADn_%C4%91%E1%BB%99ng_Qu%E1%BB%91c_gia_M%E1%BB%B9_%C4%90%C3%ACnh.jpg/330px-Kh%C3%A1n_%C4%91%C3%A0i_B_-_S%C3%A2n_v%E1%BA%ADn_%C4%91%E1%BB%99ng_Qu%E1%BB%91c_gia_M%E1%BB%B9_%C4%90%C3%ACnh.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Kh%C3%A1n_%C4%91%C3%A0i_B_-_S%C3%A2n_v%E1%BA%ADn_%C4%91%E1%BB%99ng_Qu%E1%BB%91c_gia_M%E1%BB%B9_%C4%90%C3%ACnh.jpg/440px-Kh%C3%A1n_%C4%91%C3%A0i_B_-_S%C3%A2n_v%E1%BA%ADn_%C4%91%E1%BB%99ng_Qu%E1%BB%91c_gia_M%E1%BB%B9_%C4%90%C3%ACnh.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kh%C3%A1n_%C4%91%C3%A0i_B_-_S%C3%A2n_v%E1%BA%ADn_%C4%91%E1%BB%99ng_Qu%E1%BB%91c_gia_M%E1%BB%B9_%C4%90%C3%ACnh.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/M%E1%BB%B9_%C4%90%C3%ACnh_National_Stadium" title="Mỹ Đình National Stadium">Mỹ Đình National Stadium</a> in <a href="/wiki/Hanoi" title="Hanoi">Hanoi</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Vovinam" title="Vovinam">Vovinam</a>, <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi">kim ke</i></span> and <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><i lang="vi">bình định</i></span> <a href="/wiki/Martial_arts" title="Martial arts">martial arts</a> are widespread in Vietnam,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGreen2001548_503-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGreen2001548-503">[494]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENghiaLuan2017_504-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENghiaLuan2017-504">[495]</a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">football</a> is the country's most popular sport.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE''FourFourTwo''2017_505-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE''FourFourTwo''2017-505">[496]</a></sup> Its <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_national_football_team" title="Vietnam national football team">national team</a> won the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ASEAN_Football_Championship" title="ASEAN Football Championship">ASEAN Football Championship</a> twice in <a href="/wiki/2008_AFF_Championship" title="2008 AFF Championship">2008</a> and <a href="/wiki/2018_AFF_Championship" title="2018 AFF Championship">2018</a> and reached the <a href="/wiki/2019_AFC_Asian_Cup_knockout_stage#Vietnam_vs_Japan" title="2019 AFC Asian Cup knockout stage">quarter-finals</a> of <a href="/wiki/2019_AFC_Asian_Cup" title="2019 AFC Asian Cup">2019 AFC Asian Cup</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE''China_Daily''2008_506-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE''China_Daily''2008-506">[497]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE''The_Saigon_Times_Daily''2018_507-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE''The_Saigon_Times_Daily''2018-507">[498]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGomes2019_508-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGomes2019-508">[499]</a></sup> its junior team of <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_national_under-23_football_team" title="Vietnam national under-23 football team">under-23</a> became the runners-up of <a href="/wiki/2018_AFC_U-23_Championship" title="2018 AFC U-23 Championship">2018 AFC U-23 Championship</a> and reached fourth place in <a href="/wiki/Football_at_the_2018_Asian_Games" title="Football at the 2018 Asian Games">2018 Asian Games</a>, while the <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_national_under-20_football_team" title="Vietnam national under-20 football team">under-20</a> managed to qualify the <a href="/wiki/2017_FIFA_U-20_World_Cup" title="2017 FIFA U-20 World Cup">2017 FIFA U-20 World Cup</a> for the first time in their football history.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERick2018_509-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERick2018-509">[500]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEYanJunLong2018_510-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEYanJunLong2018-510">[501]</a></sup> The national football <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_women%27s_national_football_team" title="Vietnam women's national football team">women's team</a> also traditionally dominates the <a href="/wiki/Football_at_the_Southeast_Asian_Games#Women's_tournament" title="Football at the Southeast Asian Games">Southeast Asian Games</a>, along with its chief rival, <a href="/wiki/Thailand_women%27s_national_football_team" title="Thailand women's national football team">Thailand</a>. Other Western sports such as <a href="/wiki/Badminton" title="Badminton">badminton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tennis" title="Tennis">tennis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Volleyball" title="Volleyball">volleyball</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ping-pong" title="Ping-pong">ping-pong</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chess" title="Chess">chess</a> are also widely popular. Vietnam has participated in the <a href="/wiki/Summer_Olympic_Games" title="Summer Olympic Games">Summer Olympic Games</a> since <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_at_the_1952_Summer_Olympics" title="Vietnam at the 1952 Summer Olympics">1952</a>, when it competed as the State of Vietnam. After the partition of the country in 1954, only South Vietnam competed in the games, sending athletes to the <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_at_the_1956_Summer_Olympics" title="Vietnam at the 1956 Summer Olympics">1956</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_at_the_1972_Summer_Olympics" title="Vietnam at the 1972 Summer Olympics">1972</a> Olympics. Since the reunification of Vietnam in 1976, it has competed as the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, attending every Summer Olympics from <a href="/wiki/1988_Summer_Olympics" title="1988 Summer Olympics">1988</a> onwards. The present Vietnam Olympic Committee was formed in 1976 and recognised by the <a href="/wiki/International_Olympic_Committee" title="International Olympic Committee">International Olympic Committee</a> (IOC) in 1979.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEInternational_Olympic_Committee2018_511-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEInternational_Olympic_Committee2018-511">[502]</a></sup> Vietnam has never participated in the <a href="/wiki/Winter_Olympic_Games" title="Winter Olympic Games">Winter Olympic Games</a>. In 2016, Vietnam won their first <a href="/wiki/Gold_medal" title="Gold medal">gold medal</a> at the Olympics.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESims2016_512-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESims2016-512">[503]</a></sup> Basketball has become an increasingly popular sport in Vietnam, especially in <a href="/wiki/Ho_Chi_Minh_City" title="Ho Chi Minh City">Ho Chi Minh City</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hanoi" title="Hanoi">Hanoi</a> and <span title="Vietnamese-language text"><span lang="vi" style="font-style: normal;"><a href="/wiki/S%C3%B3c_Tr%C4%83ng" title="Sóc Trăng">Sóc Trăng</a></span></span>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-513"><a href="#cite_note-513">[504]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1011085734" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="reflist reflist-lower-alpha">
</div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1011085734" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="reflist">
<div class="mw-references-wrap"><ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-2">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The Constitution of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam states that <a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_language" title="Vietnamese language">Vietnamese</a> is the "national language", rather than the "official language". However, Vietnamese is the only language used in official documents and legal proceedings.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-1"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-6"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-6">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">In effect since 1 January 2014.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Vietnam2014_5-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Vietnam2014-5">[4]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-11"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-11">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The name "Viet Nam" (with a space separating the two <a href="/wiki/Syllable" title="Syllable">syllables</a>) is formally designated and recognized by the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Vietnam" title="Government of Vietnam">Government of Vietnam</a>, the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a> and the <a href="/wiki/International_Organization_for_Standardization" title="International Organization for Standardization">International Organization for Standardization</a> as the standardized country name for Vietnam.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-12"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-12">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Also formally recognized as the <i>Socialist Republic of Viet Nam</i> by the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Vietnam" title="Government of Vietnam">Government of Vietnam</a>, the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a> and the <a href="/wiki/International_Organization_for_Standardization" title="International Organization for Standardization">International Organization for Standardization</a>.<br/><a href="/wiki/Vietnamese_language" title="Vietnamese language">Vietnamese</a>: <i lang="vi">Cộng hòa Xã hội chủ nghĩa Việt Nam</i>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-13"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-13">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Commonly known as Saigon</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-etymology-23"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-etymology_23-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-etymology_23-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">At first, <a href="/wiki/Gia_Long" title="Gia Long">Gia Long</a> requested the name "Nam Việt", but the <a href="/wiki/Jiaqing_Emperor" title="Jiaqing Emperor">Jiaqing Emperor</a> refused.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWoods200238_15-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWoods200238-15">[10]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEShaofeiGuoqing2016_22-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEShaofeiGuoqing2016-22">[17]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-119"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-119">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Neither the American government nor Ngô Đình Diệm's State of Vietnam signed anything at the 1954 Geneva Conference. The non-communist Vietnamese delegation objected strenuously to any division of Vietnam; however, the French accepted the Việt Minh proposal<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGravel1971134_115-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGravel1971134-115">[109]</a></sup> that Vietnam be united by elections under the supervision of "local commissions".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGravel1971119_116-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGravel1971119-116">[110]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a>, with the support of <a href="/wiki/South_Vietnam" title="South Vietnam">South Vietnam</a> and the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">United Kingdom</a>, countered with the "American Plan",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGravel1971140_117-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGravel1971140-117">[111]</a></sup> which provided for <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>-supervised unification elections. The plan, however, was rejected by <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet</a> and other communist delegations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKort201796_118-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKort201796-118">[112]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-area-175"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-area_175-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">See <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_area" title="List of countries and dependencies by area">List of countries and dependencies by area</a>.</span>
</li>
</ol></div></div>
